name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 5 October 2017.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before starting today's session, I would like to mention the victims of the forest fires that have occurred in Portugal and Spain in recent weeks. As I was able to say during my speech before the European Council, the phenomenon is worrying and deserves our full attention. This year alone, more than 750 000 hectares of our forests have gone up in smoke in Europe and more than 100 people have lost their lives in Portugal alone. This is why I am convinced of the need and urgency to establish a European civil protection corps and to simplify the regulatory environment, in order to allow the populations to obtain immediate help in case of need. I also inform you of the decision we have taken, in agreement with President Tusk and President Juncker, to donate to the populations affected by the forest fires the sum of money of the "Princess of Asturias" prize for concord, awarded this year to the European Union, an award that I had the honor of receiving last Friday in Oviedo. This is a symbolic way of showing our closeness to those communities and families of the numerous victims in Portugal and Spain, in remembrance of which I now propose to observe a minute of silence, during which we will also commemorate the Irish victims of the hurricane. Ophelia. (Parliament stands, observes a minute's silence) I would also like to inform the House that tomorrow, before the vote, there will be a minute of silence in memory of the Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, who was brutally killed in an attack last week. We will carry out this very short ceremony tomorrow, because tomorrow the relatives of the victim, whom I invited, will be present in the courtroom: they accepted and will be present in the stands.

name: Presidente. –
text: Let's now turn to the changes to the order of business.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry to interrupt, but the news of these last hours reports that a judge in Tehran has sentenced Ahmadreza Djalali, a university professor who teaches at the University of Stockholm and the University of Turin, in Italy to death.We have already dealt with the case of Professor Djalali in this Parliament, because we have signed a letter together with many parliamentarians asking for the intervention of the President of the Islamic Republic of Iran so that there is no intervention in this process, which is a process full of shadowsin which the professor is accused only of being, in some way, a collaborator of enemy foreign powers.It is a very serious case;The sentence was passed in recent days and I ask you to use all the influence you can have to understand what is happening and to stop this latest destruction to democracy.

name: Presidente. –
text: Hon. Viotti, You know that the fight against the death penalty around the world is a priority for the European Union, so I will do everything in my power not only to get information, but also to ask the President of the RepublicIslamic Republic of Iran to suspend the professor's execution and thus to ensure that there is no other execution in the world.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, you quite rightly called the House to order with regard to taking a minute’s silence. Could I ask the Parliament to put my remarks on record. Perhaps you would like to join me in sending condolences to the 300 victims of an al—Shabaab terrorist bomb in Mogadishu in Somalia and to many, many hundreds of victims. Perhaps that could be added to the record of the Parliament. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Absolutely yes, Hon.Carver, the European Parliament has always spoken out against terrorism.We remember the victims not only when they are European, but victims of terrorism all over the world.I therefore agree with your observation: the expression of condemnation for what happened in Mogadishu will certainly be recorded in the minutes - I believe in the name of everything in Parliament.The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules, was distributed at the meeting of Thursday 19 October 2017.The following modification proposals were presented.Monday: no change requests.Tuesday: The Verts / ALE group requested to add a resolution at the end of the debate on the Commission declaration on combating sexual harassment and abuse in the European Union, to be voted on during this part-session.I give the floor to the Hon.Ska Keller to formulate her group's request.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are going to discuss cases of sexual harassment, and, as you have surely seen, we also have reports about cases of sexual harassment happening inside the European institutions, including inside Parliament. So it is really important that we have a debate about it, but it is not enough just to talk about it. We should also put in writing what we are going to do about it – we as the European Union and as the European institutions – so that we commit ourselves to changing this horrible situation. We cannot and will not accept such harassment in this Parliament or elsewhere in the European Union. (Applause)

name: Sophia in ’t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, my Group has two requests relating to the same topic. First of all, we feel that, given the scale of the debate around the world on this topic, it should have a more prominent place on the agenda this week. We suggest that, rather than discussing it late on Tuesday night, we discuss it on Wednesday morning. The second request – and Ska Keller has already referred to an article in Politico about harassment inside the EU institutions – is that, before the next part-session, you report to us first of all about what the situation is, and secondly, what measures you are going to take to make sure that it does not happen, that when it does happen people actually have somebody to turn to, and that there are procedures for tackling this.

name: Presidente. –
text: Let's go in order. First we have to decide whether to add a resolution at the end of the discussion on the fight against sexual harassment and abuse within the Union, that is the proposal by the Hon. Ska Keller. Then there will be the proposal of the Hon. in 't Veld to change the date. But first we have to decide the content, then we will decide the date. Third thing, I answer you directly, without waiting for the next session. There is someone who wants to speak against the proposal of the Hon. Ska Keller? No. The request is put to the vote. The request is approved. Therefore, the discussion on the Commission statement on combating sexual harassment and abuse in the Union will be concluded by a resolution, to be voted on during this part-session. Hon. in 't Veld asked to change the agenda and reverse Tuesday's fifth point with the discussion on protecting workers from the risks of exposure to carcinogens or mutagens, which is scheduled for Wednesday morning. That is, he asked to have the discussion on sexual abuse on Wednesday, and instead to hold the discussion on Tuesday evening on the protection of workers against the risks deriving from exposure to carcinogens or mutagens. Is there anyone who is against this change? Please, Hon. Rodrigues.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we prefer to keep the order as it is because the Ulvskog report is also very important. Of course we know that this debate is crucial for us but we do not agree to change the order.

name: Presidente. –
text: We vote the proposal of the Hon.in 't Veld.The proposal is approved.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mister President!Ms. Keller rightly pointed out that we had media reports in the last few days that there had been incidents in the house.I would therefore like to ask Parliament's Bureau to look into this matter.The processes must be clarified immediately and whether there are any points.We have internal structures and we cannot tolerate sexual abuse of any kind in Parliament.(Applause)

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we are delighted and, of course, we also support this request made directly to the President in the Chamber.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, I agree with the idea being defended.Nevertheless, given the gravity of the facts that are occurring, including here, I find - and this will be the subject of the debate on Wednesday morning, it will figure in our proposals and I will intervene in this sense - that we cannot bejudge and party at the same time.Therefore, the idea that I will defend on Wednesday morning in my speech will be to have a study carried out by an outside firm, so as to identify exactly the reality of the facts, in all objectivity.That was the purpose of my request.

name: Presidente. –
text: I will then respond to the requests of the Hon. in 't Veld, Weber and Martin. The Commission statement on tackling sexual harassment and abuse in the Union on Tuesday afternoon is exchanged with the discussion on protecting workers from the risks of exposure to carcinogens or mutagens, currently scheduled for Wednesday morning, and there will be a resolution. As for the solicitations that came from the Hon. in 't Veld, Weber and Martin, on 14 April 2014 the Bureau set up an advisory committee on complaints of harassment involving accredited parliamentary assistants, on the one hand, and Members of the European Parliament, on the other. The committee has two main functions: to prevent any bullying behavior by deputies towards accredited parliamentary assistants and to assist the President in the framework of any investigations. The internal procedure for resolving bullying problems is initiated following a formal complaint of psychological or sexual harassment filed by an assistant against a deputy. The committee, after listening to the parliamentary assistant, decides to start an investigation if there is sufficient evidence. Both sides are invited to submit evidence to support their respective positions. At the end of the investigation, the committee transmits its recommendations to the President, who takes a decision. Such a decision may consist of a sanction, pursuant to Rule 166 of the Rules, by making the House of Parliament aware of the facts. I would add that an assistant is also on the committee. Then there is another committee that deals with problems affecting officials. I would also add that last year the committee sent to all parliamentarians a documentation, I would say a volume, to combat sexual and non-sexual pressure and harassment. It is a guide that has been sent to all the deputies with the names of the members as well who are part of the committee. This evening, of course, I will inform the Bureau, the Bureau of Parliament, to evaluate all initiatives in this regard; I will listen to Quaestor Morin-Chartier, who is responsible for leading this group, for all the necessary information. Naturally, anyone who has been subjected to harassment of this type must turn, as is required by our rules, to this committee that will make all necessary investigations. Since there is a committee chaired by a Quaestor elected by the Plenary, I do not believe that, given the sovereignty of Parliament, there should be investigations to be entrusted to outsiders. The inquiries are to be made by the ad hoc committee, chaired by a Quaestor elected by Parliament, and a parliamentary assistant also belongs to this committee. So everything that needs to be done will be done. It is unacceptable that events of this type occur, I hope they will be very limited in Parliament. Then we will see the number of people, but until now we do not have such a large number of complaints. But even if it were just one case it would be, as far as I'm concerned, unacceptable. I have already said in the past, when I had to take a disciplinary decision against a colleague of ours, what is my opinion on the role of women in European society, so from this point of view I will be inflexible in inflicting harsh penalties on parliamentarians who violated our code and rules. Wednesday: The Verts / ALE group requested that the joint discussion on the entry / exit system, currently scheduled for Wednesday morning, be postponed to a later part-session.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to ask that we postpone this vote because the European Court of Justice decided in July that the Passenger Data Agreement with Canada cannot be concluded, and one of the main reasons was illegal data retention. The court made clear that data about European travellers cannot, in general, be retained for years by Canadian authorities. But now, with the entry/exit system, we would actually retain for years the personal data of Canadians coming to Europe – i.e. we would be doing exactly the same to our counterparts, and I really do not see how we could explain that to our Canadian partners. Therefore, we have requested an independent legal analysis of the implications of the court decision, which we will publish tomorrow. That study says clearly that the entry/exit system poses serious problems because the data retention periods are far too long and not justifiable, and because rules on access by law-enforcement agencies are not specific enough – and I think that we as Parliament should not adopt EU legislation that will likely be struck down again by the Court. At the very least, we would ask for help to postpone the vote until we can have more legal expertise on the matter and study it carefully. Therefore, we propose to postpone the vote.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. president. On my own behalf, and on behalf of my group, I reject this claim of the Group of the Greens, for many very important reasons, but mainly for three reasons. First of all, because the Regulation contains a robust data protection system. Mr Buttarelli - the European data protection supervisor - is the guarantor of the correct use, retention, treatment and storage of data. This is contemplated in the Regulation. Secondly, the legal services of the three institutions - the Legal Service of the Council, the Commission and the Parliament - have said, orally and in writing and also at the request of the Group of the Greens, they have categorically stated that opinion1 / 15, which refers to the European Union-Canada PNR, has no impact on the Regulation establishing an Entry and Exit System. And, third and very important. It will be remembered by all - and especially by German colleagues - that there was a terrorist attack on the Berlin Christmas market. Well, I want to tell you that the attacker, the terrorist, used fifteen different identities. If the Regulation establishing an Entry and Exit System had been in force, this would never have been possible. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I beg you on Wednesday to discuss and, where appropriate, vote on the Regulation establishing an Entry and Exit System.

name: Presidente. –
text: I put to the vote the request of the Verts / ALE Group, which asks that the discussion on the entry / exit system, scheduled for Wednesday morning, be postponed to a later part-session.The request is rejected, so the agenda remains unchanged.Wednesday: The GUE / NGL group asked to change the agenda for Wednesday's discussions as follows: Council and Commission statements on forest fire response mechanisms in northern Spain and Portugal will be the first item on Wednesday afternoon, before the discussion on topical issues.

name: João Ferreira
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, since today you had the opportunity to pay tribute to the victims of the fires in Portugal and you had the opportunity to point out how this is a matter of the greatest importance - and it is, in fact - in the face of these tragedies, these catastrophes, it is important to discuss no only the support that needs to be mobilized immediately to provide victims and their families, but also to discuss an appropriate framework for the prevention of this type of catastrophe at European level. This is an issue that, therefore, does not concern only the two States that, last week, were most directly affected by the fires - it is an issue that concerns everyone. Bearing in mind the importance of the subject - which you yourself stressed, and very well -, what we wanted was to give visibility and a projection to this debate that placing it at ten o'clock at night or at eleven o'clock on Wednesday night does not guarantee and Hence, therefore, we propose to change it to the first item on the agenda in the afternoon, that is, at three in the afternoon.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: - (NL) Madam President, of course it is terrible when people die in a forest fire, but I think this is an example of weak symbolic politics.I did not hear the GUE / NGL Group on the subject of the terrible earthquake in Italy - which must also be of personal concern to you.But now that we are talking about this and we happen to have brought up the topic for the current affairs debate, it suddenly has to be postponed and another debate has to be put in front of it.It is the custom here in this House that current affairs debates come first on Wednesday afternoon, and I would ask you to respect this custom.I know there are parliamentarians here who violate their own assistants - an appalling disrespect for their fellow man.Here, too, I recognize such a lack of respect in this proposal.I hope we all vote against.

name: Presidente. –
text: I put the request of the Hon.Ferreira, on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group, to change the agenda and bring the debate on forest fires in Portugal and Spain to the first item on Wednesday afternoon.The request is rejected, so the agenda is not changed.The order of business was thus established.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Mihai Ţurcanu, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down rules for the making available on the market of fertilising products bearingCE marking and amending regulations (EC) n.1069/2009 and (EC) no.1107/2009 (COM (2016) 0157 - C8-0123 / 2016 - 2016/0084 (COD)) (A8-0270 / 2017).

name: Mihai Ţurcanu
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the draft regulation laying down rules on European-branded fertilizers aims to improve current legislation in this area. Please allow me to present some arguments that led me to believe in this report. I would like to point out, first of all, that this regulation is part of the Commission's proposal on the circular economy. It will have a positive impact on all European Union countries, and the benefits will be reflected in several areas of activity. The economic sector, first of all, is a good engine through which the profile industry is stimulated to become more competitive. Among the notable objectives of this legislative framework is that the scope of fertilizers will be extended to those obtained from secondary raw materials. The administrative burdens on producers will be reduced and labeling will be clearer and more comprehensive. On the other hand, the consumer, the one we want to protect, will have safer products. We want the presence of heavy metals and contaminants in fertilizers to be within limits that do not endanger human health. I would like to emphasize that, as rapporteur, we have made efforts to reach the widest possible consensus, despite the contradictory positions that persist between the countries of the European Union on this issue. It is our duty to provide European consumers with food that is safe for health and at a reasonable price. I would also like to review the main provisions of the proposal, namely that the proposal will allow all fertilizers, including those derived from bio-waste and recycled nutrients, to benefit from the CE marking, which will ensure free movement in the single market. New harmonized requirements will be introduced for all CE marked fertilising products in terms of quality, safety and labeling. We are also talking about new rules on the free movement of all CE marked fertilizers. Optional harmonization will be maintained; for example, a manufacturer who does not want his product to bear the CE marking but has unlimited access to the entire EU single market may opt for compliance with national rules, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. We had consultations with representatives of national delegations and political groups, discussed with representatives of the chemical fertilizer industry of the Member States, as well as of some countries exporting raw materials to the European Union. On Tuesday, you are called upon to vote on several proposed limits for the maximum permitted cadmium concentration. Please keep in mind the need for the most urgent regulation in this area, as well as the need for the industry to have the necessary time to adapt to the new standards. Dear colleagues, we do not have the right to close factories overnight, to leave thousands of people without work. We do not have the right to condemn European farmers to buy fertilizer products at prices that harm them. But we cannot continue to allow European soil and, implicitly, agriculture to evolve chaotically and unsustainably, with risks for our safety and that of other consumers. That is why I believe it is necessary to establish, from the entry into force of the future regulation, a precise level of cadmium allowed. We must also be aware that a reasonable implementation time is needed. I believe in the professionalism of my colleagues and I want to harmonize our positions so that we can present ourselves with our heads held high in front of our own voters. Dear colleagues, beyond this point, which I know many of you will continue to comment on, I would like to point out that the report is, to a large extent, the result of the work done by the previous head. of the file, Ms Gáll-Pelcz, until she left the European Parliament.Thank you for your effort.I also thank my colleagues who contributed suggestions and proposals, in particular Mr Andreas Schwab, for his consistent contribution as EPP Coordinator in the Committee on the Internal Market.I conclude by calling for your support, especially as negotiations with the European Council will follow.In their perspective, we need a stronger mandate from the European Parliament forum.Thank you.

name: Elisabetta Gardini
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am here to witness a work that has been laborious, long and complex. We welcomed this regulation with great favor, because it includes under the CE mark a vast field of fertilizers that were previously excluded, but we also have some concerns. We, as the Environment Committee, had exclusive competence with regard to contaminants and the point on which we debated the most was certainly that of cadmium, as the rapporteur Ţurcanu has already mentioned. My concerns are very strong because even in the fact sheets of the Commission it is estimated that already going to a limit of 40 milligrams would require great efforts and greater investments in technologies, etc. etc., but the Commission itself recognizes in these documents that even going to 20 milligrams , as the Commission has proposed and as the Environment Commission has also confirmed, would entail such and greater investments in decay and probably would even require a general reorganization of the fertilizer market. This is why I believe that prudence is important and that perhaps it is right to give ourselves some time to reflect, considering that starting from 60 milligrams we are already halfway through the lowest limit we find in the world. You know, from 120 to 150-160 we are talking about the United States, we are talking about Canada, we are talking about Australia: we are certainly not talking about countries that do not care about the environment. So I join the appeal of the rapporteur Ţurcanu.

name: Jan Huitema
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, modern agriculture is capable of providing solutions to climate change, a better environment and more biodiversity through ecological and technological innovations. For this it is necessary to adjust European regulations. For example, outdated legislation restricts a farmer from fertilizing his land with animal manure from his own farm. He must dispose of the surplus animal manure. In order to still meet the fertilization needs of his crop, he buys fertilizer. The world upside down. The farmer should be able to use his own fertilizers as much as possible instead of buying fertilizers. For comparison, we annually import 6 million tons of phosphate fertilizer, while we could recover 2 million tons of phosphate from organic sources such as manure and waste streams. We must close this cycle. This reduces the burden on the environment and reduces greenhouse gas emissions. Fortunately, the European Commission wants to make this possible. In addition, phosphate fertilizers can contain the carcinogenic cadmium. That is a major risk to our environment and food safety that we cannot allow. That is why I am voting for strict cadmium limits in fertilizers. Industry arguments that the price of fertilizers will increase drastically and farmers will pay the price has been scare tactics and has been contradicted by agricultural economists. In fact, the reverse is true. I don't want farmers to be labeled as environmental criminals in a few years' time because cadmium is found in the soil, or worse, in our food. Because they use fertilizers that comply with European rules, European rules that we make here today. In addition, a new fertilizers regulation offers sufficient possibilities for alternatives. With the new fertilizers regulation, there is finally more room for it organic fertilizers to compete with fertilizers.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to express my thanks to Parliament for its strong support for the proposed Fertilising Products Regulation. In particular, I thank the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs for all their valuable input. The regulation is in many ways ground-breaking and also very complex. Being here today gives me a chance to recall its core principles. First of all, with regard to the potential of the circular economy, the proposed regulation is the first deliverable of the Circular Economy Action Plan. It is a very ambitious contribution to that. I say very ambitious because, for the first time, this regulation will open up the single market for products needed by European farmers in the 21st century. The products I am talking about are innovative agro-chemicals produced from organic materials present in by-products and waste. Those products have enormous potential to make European agriculture more efficient and sustainable and to create jobs and opportunities for innovative businesses in Europe. When organic materials available in Europe are recycled, European farmers get an outlet for agricultural by-products that would otherwise have been wasted. European fertiliser manufacturers become much less dependent on imported, scarce raw materials, such as phosphate, from other regions in the world and, in between, a market is created for innovative European recycling operators and technology providers. So this is a win-win for European farmers, fertiliser producers and innovative businesspeople. In terms of a free market for responsible actors, we are trying with the proposed new regulation to free up the market as much as possible for products that can reform the European agro-industry. Gone are the days when fertilisers had to comply with narrow definitions set by the legislator, or when they had to be halted at every border between Member States for new certification. Nowadays, manufacturers have real freedom to adapt their products to farmers’ needs, using a mix of conventional and innovative raw materials. Farmers understand their own needs much better than any legislator. That is why we have proposed legislation which keeps farmers’ choices as wide as possible. But this presumes that manufacturers take all responsibility for product safety. Spreading products on farmland can pose a risk to health and the environment. Known and unknown toxic contaminants can end up in our water, food and animal feed. So we have proposed that all agro-chemicals covered in the legislation must be subject to a chemical safety assessment under the general Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) legislation. If this proposal is amended, nobody – neither the legislator nor the manufacturer – will be responsible for assessing the safety of using agro-chemicals on land, and crops. That could have dramatic impacts on the environment and on the safety of the food chain, so I urge the European Parliament not to water down our proposal on this point. European fertiliser producers are more than able to take on the responsibility that the new market freedom requires and European farmers and citizens have the right to expect. Finally, this proposal not only provides new opportunities for the European agro-industry, it also provides you with an opportunity to limit emissions of toxic contaminants to farmland, drinking water and food. I would like to thank you for your general support for this part of our proposal. Together, we will raise environmental standards in an area in which Europeans are lagging behind the rest of the world. Future generations of Europeans will have their health better protected. A particular concern for health and the environment is cadmium in phosphate fertilisers. As far back as 1988, a Council resolution called for a strategy to reduce cadmium in phosphate fertilisers, and the problem has far from disappeared since then. There are a few marginal scientific differences, but the overall picture is clear: the European environment and people are too exposed to cadmium, and the only remaining major polluter of food in the environment is the phosphate fertilisers industry. So it is time for phosphate fertiliser manufacturers make sure that some of the dirtiest phosphate rock is cleaned before it is used in fertilisers, or for them to replace it with cleaner recycled phosphates sourced from Europe. And they can do that. The market is already developing and we are ready to support it further. Please remember that the limit values will also apply to imported phosphate fertilisers sold in the single market with the CE mark. This gives the European industry a golden opportunity to lead the world, not only as manufacturers of clean fertilisers with access to the single market, but also as technology providers to importers. So the industry should work with us, not against us. It is in their interest. It will help them to get a competitive advantage by developing clean technologies in innovative ways. To conclude my opening remarks, let me thank you again for your support. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, there is one thing I do not understand: how come the Commission can ask for and pay for scientific research, and when the time comes to write European law, this research is thrown out with the garbage? The Smolders study, which should be the basis for the findings of the Commission and for our work as well, shows that 80 mg of cadmium per kilogramme in fertilisers does not lead to accumulation of cadmium in the soil. Don’t make any mistakes: this proposal will not lead to lowering our dependence on imports of phosphate or phosphorus rock. We will be dependant on different sources. What we’re doing right now is we’re going to stuff euros into the Russian hands, and that’s a fact. Please don’t ask me to go back to my home country and tell those people who are going to lose their European jobs that we are doing this to help them out, because it is not true. it is not based on good science, it is not based on good economy, and it is just crazy. We should not propose such a law, because it does not make any sense.

name: Pilar Ayuso
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I welcome this legislation, which is part of the circular economy package, because it proposes organic and recycled fertilizers, thus reducing inorganic raw material. And, in addition, harmonious environmental and food safety criteria are established to promote the trade of these products. All of this is very good and highly commendable. They are great goals that we have to pursue, but sometimes the end does not justify the means, especially if these means that we have are not viable or feasible from a practical and economic point of view for the sectors that have to assume and apply them. . Favoring the expansion of organic matter is very positive. However, we cannot thereby pretend to substitute mineral products, at least as long as we do not ensure that they provide the same level and efficiency in terms of soil fertilization. Do not forget that fertilizer products are essential and guarantee farmers that their crops receive a sufficient supply of nutrients. On the other hand, although it is important to promote the use of manures as organic fertilizers, I believe that this is not the regulation to try, as it would directly affect the Nitrates Directive. I also want to refer, of course, to the maximum cadmium content. The permitted cadmium limits have generated a lot of debate and have a great impact on the competitiveness of industry and agriculture, as well as other geopolitical connotations, as just said here. In my opinion the limits proposed by the Commission are too low. Furthermore, I would say that they are unacceptable and the proposal must be made more flexible: eighty milligrams, as scientific reports point out, would be a reasonable figure, especially when we now have no limits. In any case, we must promote this Regulation to support the industry so that become more sustainable and competitive, and foster sustainable economic growth and employment.But if we go too far on some issues, we will have to vote against it.

name: Marc Tarabella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a regulation we are discussing today aims to guarantee the functioning of the internal market in fertilizer products, while ensuring that CE marked fertilizers meet the requirements of protection of the human, animal and plant health and environmental safety. Fertilizers are obviously crucial for agricultural production, but their use can also have a negative impact on the environment and food security, especially when they contain contaminants. At present, fertilizers are regulated at European level by the 2003 regulation. However, the latter only covers part of the fertilizer market, since around 50% of all fertilizers present on the European market are excluded from its scope. Indeed, the existing regulation mainly concerns conventional, so-called "inorganic" fertilizers, which follow a linear economic model, since it involves the extraction of raw materials. The proposed regulation, on the other hand, initiates a shift towards the circular economy, as it aims to increase the reuse of raw materials that are currently disposed of as waste. Putting organic fertilizers on an equal footing with traditional fertilizers can reduce waste and the environmental impact of fertilization and agriculture. It is estimated that the recovery of nutrients already present in the European Union, for example in the form of waste, could replace around 30% of the inorganic fertilizers currently on the market - this has been specified previously. This is a very technical file, with a complex division of powers between the various committees involved. The colleagues and I worked together to obtain a text that is in my opinion well balanced. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Ţurcanu, who took over from Mrs Gall-Pelcz, who had done an excellent job, as well as my other shadow rapporteur colleagues for their collaboration. I therefore hope that tomorrow's vote will consolidate the achievements we have achieved through the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. However, at the present time, I am challenged by the possible reopening of the "nitrates" directive, which nevertheless, from the start, was a red line for my group and which, by mutual agreement, was unthinkable in this context. report. Indeed, the "nitrates" directive includes two major elements: on the one hand, the principle of balanced fertilization and, on the other hand, the obligation to limit the use of manure, making it possible to avoid intensive breeding and to promote sustainable agriculture. So it is not a question of the time or place to hastily amend essential legislation to combat soil pollution. I would add that if the 'nitrates' amendment were to pass - which had been proposed at various stages of the dossier - I would instruct my group to vote against the entire report. I think we should not take this risk. As for the thorny issue of cadmium thresholds, the compromise supported in particular by my group seems to me to be the most balanced solution, because it makes it possible to apply the precautionary principle in the matter, while giving the industry time. to comply with these new requirements.

name: Edward Czesak
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The Commission's proposal introducing a drastic reduction in the limit values ​​for contamination of fertilizers with heavy metals, mainly cadmium, is controversial. The project directly affects the fertilizer industry based on the exploitation of native resources of phosphorus rocks in many EU countries. EU fertilizer producers will be forced to significantly increase production costs through either expensive heavy metal ore cleaning or importing mineral ores with lower levels of contamination from any of the global exporters. I am thinking mainly of Russia. As a consequence, this will worsen the economic situation of the chemical industry in the European Union and will increase the prices of fertilizers. It also threatens with a significant loss of jobs. The standards proposed in the report are drastic, and the argument for the protection of the environment and consumer health, although important, there are no clear results of studies indicating the need for such strict limitation of heavy metal content in fertilizer production. The new regulations must be realistic. Member States with decades of powerful chemical plants - some of them being the main employers in the region - cannot be required to suddenly shift from synthetic fertilizers to the production of organic fertilizers. By voting, I urge you to bear in mind that the adoption of a report imposing such stringent environmental standards on the European market will significantly hinder our national producer from operating on the European fertilizer market. It will also open the field for broadly understood external actions, unfavorable for the companies of our European market. The amendments tabled by the ECR group covering 80 ml / kg of cadmium in phosphorus fertilizers give a chance that the final shape of the report will take into account the implementation of the gradual reduction of heavy metals content in fertilizers, but also reasonably spread over time.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there has been a lot of talk around cadmium, but I will not talk about cadmium: this proposal is not only setting the limits, it is also about opening new possibilities for European producers. Up until now, only mineral fertilisers have benefited from the CE marking and free access to the single market. Today, they are still the most widely used in Europe, but alongside the traditional products more and more companies are looking for new solutions. This partly reflects the global trend in rising environmental consciousness on the one hand, and a drive for increased efficiency on the other. Companies around the world realise that they need to find ways to do more with less.  In Europe, a lot of effort has been put into innovation. There is a strong drive in the fertiliser sector to find new sources of raw materials and make products that are more targeted and less wasteful. Often the solutions that are found are at the very forefront of science. By extending the scope of this regulation to such products, we will put in place the necessary framework to maximise the innovative potential of the fertiliser industry. Unified European standards will give producers a clear set of targets to aim for. Removing national barriers from the market will give them access to enough customers to make their investments pay off. Moreover, by asking the Commission to keep looking for new component materials that could be added to the regulation, we recognise that a lot of the potential of this sector is still untapped. We should not only reward existing animation by granting better access to the single market, we should also encourage further research by ensuring the possibility of updating the regulation in the future. By allowing the Commission to revise the regulation, we are telling producers to think outside the box and to keep looking for new solutions. If we follow these principles, we can create legislation that is truly supportive of innovation.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, in the field of fertilizers and in the context of the circular economy, we believe that work should be done to reduce the use of chemical fertilizers, developing agroecology and promoting a greater interrelationship between livestock and agriculture, enhancing the use of manure. and promoting composting on the farms themselves, so that women and men farmers are increasingly less dependent on factors of production from abroad and to avoid a greater environmental impact and contribute to the fight against climate change. This would also mean reducing production costs, the consumption of fossil energies and the danger of the release of substances harmful to the environment and the health of both people and animals. With regard to phosphate rock, one of the fundamental raw materials for fertilizers that the European Union imports, it must be said that it comes mainly from Morocco, from deposits in the occupied territories in Western Sahara. This rock also has high levels of cadmium, which accumulates in soil and water and passes through the food chain, causing health and environmental problems. We believe that the European institutions must guarantee the sovereignty of the people of the Sahara over their resources, prevent them from being plundered by Morocco and not give in to external pressure regarding the establishment of permitted levels of cadmium in fertilizers. We believe it is necessary to stop imports of substances for the manufacture of fertilizers. And sewage sludge must not be allowed in fertilizers. For us, the CE marking should be reserved exclusively for European Union products. The labeling must be clear, transparent and easily understandable. Labels must be written in all the official languages ​​of the Member States. In the conformity assessment procedure, it must be ensured that the precautionary principle always prevails. For this, Conformity assessment bodies must be public and based on independent, transparent and public studies and assessments and must be updated continuously.Only in this way can we guarantee that we are not selling fertilizers with the CE marking that present a risk to human, animal or plant health, or to the environment.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we all know what we are trying to do here. We are trying to create one internal market for all fertilisers, because we know that until now the scope has been very limited. When we are doing that, then one of the key issues is going to be the level of cadmium that is allowed because we all know, it is a fact: cadmium is a heavy metal and carcinogenic to people. We know that, and we also know – this was already investigated by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) – that in 2009 Europeans’ intake of cadmium was at the maximum limit set by EFSA, and the intake for some more vulnerable groups there was a higher of cadmium than was allowed. These are concerning facts that need to be addressed, because we also know that of all the cadmium limits, until now only the fertiliser group has been exempted. If we are going to make a European regulation – and we know that there are many national applications in place – we have to take into consideration that the proposals by the Commission entail, for some countries, a dilution of the current cadmium limits. That is on the table, and then people are saying that this will hamper the fertiliser industry. To them I say: ‘excuse me, can we base this kind of debate on facts?’ Wageningen University have been looking after the research and they say that the cost of meeting the cadmium limits that are being proposed would be minimal. And reducing cadmium limits would also be a stimulus for innovation: getting to clean fertiliser without cadmium would be an example of the circular economy. That is what we are trying to do here. Most of the arguments you hear positing that this is impossible are predicated on a very old-fashioned idea that innovation is not happening. If we can be innovative Europe then we can be the selling market for clean fertilisers. That is what is at stake, and we don’t want to hear any flippant discussions. What is also very important is that in the end, if we are not doing this right, who will pay the price? It is the farmers still using the contaminated fertilisers, because they must use the market. And if we find out there is more and more cadmium in our soils, and who will be getting the blame? It is the farmers. So if you are really concerned about the farmers, you have to make sure that the producers get the limits that they need to get. And that is at stake and all the other arguments are just fake.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the onus of proof must always lie with those who impose the restriction. Regulation must not been made for regulation’s sake, and the rule is made for people and not the other way around. Restrictions and prohibitions must be justified. This means a real risk to human health – not just a hazard. All actions are hazardous, and if that were the criterion we would all do nothing. We would still be living in caves with much shorter lifespans.  It also means looking at the real—world impact of this legislation. Are substitutes available? Can the damage of the restriction be mitigated? Have we used a sledgehammer to crack a nut? There is no clear evidence that we need to crack down hard on cadmium, and lots of economic consequences which are real and damaging. Fertilisers are a cost, but they allow modern agricultural productivity essential for the size of the world’s growing population. I am a farmer, and I can tell you that no sensible farmer applies any fertiliser he does not regard as essential, and he selects the most cost-effective option. We believe that the case for a 20 mg cadmium restriction has simply not been made. It will further burden EU agriculture with no identifiable benefit. Limits in the United States, Canada and Australia are over 120 mg, but their people are not suffering. So how can it possibly make sense to add to the cost, enrich the Russians, handicap EU production and reduce our competitiveness? Also, what are we going to do with all this cadmium that we do pull out of the phosphate, if indeed we do that? That is when it will become a real hazard.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, updating the market for fertilizers bearing the "CE" mark is essential to comply with the requirements for the protection of health, safety and the environment. Currently, only traditional fertilizers obtained by extraction or by chemical processes enjoy access to the internal market and have the famous "CE" label, while 50% of the fertilizers currently on the market are excluded - organic, by-products animals or agricultural, biological waste. As a result, fertilizers obtained on the basis of circular economy principles are currently excluded. This initiative, this text therefore has two objectives. The first is to encourage the production in the European Union of fertilizers from organic or secondary materials to develop the circular economy model by transforming waste into nutrients, thus reducing the European Union's dependence on nutrients imported from third countries. This proposal aims to establish a level playing field for organic fertilizers with mineral fertilizers. The second objective is to establish limit levels for contaminants in fertilizers. The rates proposed by the Commission are impractical and dangerous for the industry using phosphate as a natural source for the preparation of its secondary fertilizers. The French organic or secondary fertilizer industry is very developed and has every interest in benefiting from the opening of the internal market and the granting of the "CE" label. These economic players are de facto distorted from competition in the market for mineral and chemical fertilizers. The support obtained by French civil society on this issue testifies to the real stakes for this particular sector of the French economy, and I would like to thank them here. On the other hand, the support on this file from the French deputies of all parties policies of this Chamber are still expected from the actors of this sector. In addition to the vital issue for the French phosphate fertilizer industry, the Commission's proposal would also have the bad idea of ​​making us depend on only one source of supply of phosphates and the collapse of the northern phosphate market. Africa could have serious repercussions on the social balance of these countries. Geopolitical interest is also an important issue in this text. Our group tabled amendments aiming to establish a cadmium rate at 80 milligrams per kilo, with a gradual decrease over fifteen years to obtain a rate of 60 milligrams, a reasonable and pragmatic timeframe for research and development, particularly in decadmiation techniques phosphate. The French delegation of the National Front could not therefore tomorrow, during the vote, choose to sacrifice too many French jobs by an ideological logic and devoid of common sense, by choosing much too low cadmium levels. It is arguably preferable that the French secondary and organic fertilizer industry accepts the status quo by remaining temporarily excluded from the single market, rather than risk seeing many of its employees being made redundant. The instrumentalisation of an economic need for the benefit of contradictory objectives does not seem to me the best way to help the European industrial fabric.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the whole idea of the circular economy is just catching on, so it is appropriate that we try and implement it in the agriculture sector with fertilisers. Frankly, for a lot a farmers, they try to operate a circular economy on their farm where they have animals and cropping, and it can work really well. It can also work at the local level – amongst farmers who trade in livestock manure, and I think that is something we should encourage and promote. In this case, what we are talking about is extending what can be used as a fertiliser ingredient. What we need from that is that it is effective – in other words, that it works at farm level and that it is safe and that we do not over-regulate. What is very important is that fertilisers in the past account for 60% of the registered yield increase in the last 50 years, so we absolutely need fertilisers to grow crops. I have listened carefully to the robust debate about cadmium, and I think we have to make sure that what we aspire to is achievable and does not have unintended consequences. I would say here that the cereal sector in Europe is under huge pressure. We import a large volume of cereals that will be produced without our control on the cadmium levels used in the fertilisers in third countries, and we need to be very mindful of the consequences of that on our production here. It is one of the things that we do repeatedly in Europe. I want us to be leaders in this field, but I do not want us to be so far ahead that we are behind. We do it in a whole range of products. If we can encourage the rest of the world to move with us, then I think we could all do that in a very coherent and supportive way. I fear, though, that in this case we will be so far ahead that we are behind and will cause problems on the single market for our farmers, and indeed for our consumers.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulation we will approve tomorrow will give us a finally harmonized regulatory framework in a sector, that of fertilizers, which - I would like to remind all of us - represents 100,000 jobs in Europe, hundreds of small and medium-sized enterprises , with an annual turnover ranging from 20 to 25 billion euros. I would like to underline three important results that emerge from this text. The first is visible, legible and complete CE labeling, which will ensure greater protection for consumers and, above all, for farmers. The second: we have guaranteed the promotion of the use of recycled and organic materials for a further development of the circular economy and the reduction of dependence on the import of some raw materials from third countries. Finally, there is what remains the most sensitive point of the regulation, namely the definition of harmonized limit values ​​on certain contaminating products, such as cadmium and chromium. I believe that the approach that our group has brought to Parliament's attention is one of reasonableness and balance. On the one hand, attention to citizens' health and environmental safety, on the other hand the need for reasonable times for adapting the industrial system to the new limits set, new limits which, I would like to remind you all, in most European countries are clearly lower than the starting limit of this directive, that is, the 60 milligrams that we have put as a starting point. I think some might argue that it could have been faster to reach a harmonized framework at European level. However, what matters - I think, colleagues - is to start a process in Europe which, through investments, research and development, makes this sector more competitive and our policies more environmentally sustainable.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we welcome much of this report and the modernisation of the current regulation, but the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has simply gone too far on cadmium levels, which they had competence on. Their proposal to lower the amount of cadmium fertilisers to just 40 mg in three years and then just 20 mg in nine years goes against scientific evidence and would have a dramatic effect on our ability to produce food. Our farmers need affordable and high—quality fertilisers. They directly increase the productivity of many crops. The Commission proposed 60 mg, even though they had evidence that 80 mg would do the job and lead to a reduction in the accumulation of cadmium in the soil. Fertilisers, we should also remember, are only one reason that cadmium can end up in the soil and in diet: alone, they don’t solve the problem. The EU imports 85% of fertilisers, and most of those inputs will not meet the 60 mg proposal, let alone the 40 mg target or the 20 mg target down the line. So, if this report goes through, our farmers will face massive cost increases, which will make our food even more expensive. I therefore urge colleagues to support the amendments tabled by the ECR Group, which sets a maximum level at 80 mg.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: - Mr President! Thank you, Commission, for your presence in this very important debate. I would also like to thank the Commission for being very open and accessible throughout the process, where we have handled very technical legislation, but where we have been able to get quick answers to important questions to move forward in the work. First of all, it is important to point out the new markets that we may actually see. It sounds a bit like doomsday is approaching when I hear the right flank debate here. But that is not the case at all. First, we should probably start by stating that what we are talking about are not absolute levels of prohibition that set obstacles and limits. If you are from the UK and want to allow 150 milligrams of cadmium in mineral fertilizers, you can actually do so. The difference is that you are not allowed to sell it under the CE marking, which is the guarantee of what you are allowed to sell on the European market. That's what we'm actually talking about. But some here, it feels like, are very hard pressed by an industrial lobby that wants to access the entire European market. Then we have to ask ourselves the question: What is the average level today? It is 34 milligrams. That is well below the 40 milligrams that we aim to achieve in three years. At the same time, several countries - the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Finland, Sweden, Hungary and more - already have much lower levels today. Three of them have 20 milligrams or 22 milligrams. Well-functioning countries with well-functioning agricultural industry. This of course indicates that it is possible to do. But then we must have clear signals, and although I think that in our compromise here we are now eroding a lot by extending the time perspective to 16 years, it may be a compromise I can live with so that we can get this on banana. The consequence, if we drive 80 milligrams, is not about your home market, it is about what Hungary will have to accept. That you quadruple their levels? What will Finland need to accept? That you quadruple the level of cadmium in their mineral fertilizers?We can not do that.We need to be more progressive than that.Thank you to the Commission for your good cooperation and we hope that we will have a good result in the vote.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, any intervention in this field of making fertilizer products available on the market must not lose sight of the fact that dominant European agriculture deviates from fundamental aspects of a sustainable production model, to which the prevailing policies and guidelines will not be unaware. in the European Union, as is the case with the CAP, which need a profound change. The rapporteur considers that Member States should be free to admit non-harmonized fertilizers to the internal market, without removing the possibility for economic operators to opt for the benefits of a harmonized regulatory framework. If, on the one hand, it seems advisable to restrict the effects of harmonization, making it optional, on the other hand, on the other hand, the criteria that will have governed the elaboration of the harmonized regulatory framework seem more questionable. These criteria would be expected to ensure high standards of quality, safety and protection, both of the environment and of public health, which encourage or, at least, do not compromise product and process innovation and align with the best knowledge technical and scientific resources available, in addition to not benefiting certain types of interests and economically more powerful operators to the detriment of others. There are legitimate doubts that this is so.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I think one goal was very clear that we would get uniform regulation in Europe. We have come closer to the goal. But allow me a few words about cadmium. I am actually surprised by the debate on the other side of some colleagues. Now we are measuring ourselves - unfortunately they are no longer there - with the USA and Australia and say they have higher values ​​- so that would be a competitive disadvantage for Europe. If you were to do the same with many other things, then we would be way behind in our consumer and environmental standards. Therefore: Europe has to be a trendsetter. You have to go first in what is possible. And what the Environment Committee has proposed for cadmium is just a possibility. Everything that is in the soil at some point will also end up in the food. Everything we can avoid, we must avoid now. Therefore it is a precautionary measure that may also cost money - no question about it - but which must be taken in the long term to protect the environment. We want more natural fertilizers + that must take precedence over chemical mineral fertilizers. It is very clear. We also support this objective. But these funds must also be clean. Allow me to make a few points that we do not think are really well resolved. One is that the fertilizer ordinance must in no way lead to higher nitrate inputs from manure being allowed. There is a risk that the Nitrates Directive will be weakened by the Fertilizer Ordinance. The definition of animal fertilizer in the nitrates directive must not be affected by the fertilizer ordinance. It is clear that the excessive nutrient input leads to environmental and health damage. Sustainable agricultural systems should not be weakened by the fertilizer ordinance either. A point of us having REACH is a matter of concern.The fertilizer regulation must not be used to circumvent the REACH regulation.This means that no chemical substances may be used in fertilizers that can be harmful to human health or the environment.The proposal for a regulation on fertilizers contains a number of amendments which would make it possible to use fertilizers that are authorized without proper risk management.In the case of biostimulants, too, we are concerned that not only natural substances are used, but that, in the end, perhaps a circumvention is created and pesticides are used.I would like to add a special point: plastic sheets as mulch sheets, which should then rot in the field.I can only warn against that.This will help ensure that we have more plastic in the soil and in the water.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the food we eat is the main source of contamination by heavy metals, including cadmium, which is classified as a carcinogen. We are told by EFSA, which also established tolerable maximum intake levels in its scientific opinions. A study by the Experimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie, in 2015, found that those who follow a vegetarian or vegan Mediterranean diet are also more exposed to high levels of cadmium and therefore to contamination. By introducing stringent limits for cadmium and other heavy metals, such as mercury, arsenic and lead, into this new regulation, we can secure the health of European consumers. Not doing it today would be insane and irresponsible. We also have another great opportunity to seize, that of the circular economy, to make a concept up to now abstract into something concrete. This regulation seeks to transform waste into resources and create an organic fertilizer market to encourage natural and clean fertilizers. And in this way we could obtain a double result: on the one hand, decrease Europe's dependence on imports of raw materials, such as phosphate rocks, the main ingredient of inorganic mineral fertilizers, which, however, we often buy from areas of the world where not only these rocks are contaminated and very dirty, but in which their extraction violates human rights. On the other hand, we would favor a real transition towards sustainable and natural agriculture that is beneficial for ecosystems, the environment and, of course, man. We are talking about a CE mark and we are talking about stringent criteria to create a new market. Those who do not respect them can stay out and continue business as usual, but we must aim for the maximum and the improvement of the health of European citizens.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF).
text: - Mr President, it is with my concerns as a farmer that I have studied this report. Let us not forget, farmers are the first users of these fertilizers, a profession which unfortunately sometimes feels excluded from the decisions of the European Union, which also feels misunderstood, and even despised. I therefore welcome, for once, the desire to have included our voice, that of the Members of the Agriculture Committee, in this text. The second remark concerns the yield of organic fertilizers. You have to be sure that these are as effective as the products they are supposed to replace. This is a non-negotiable requirement, because it could jeopardize the survival of agriculture, of course, which already has to face competition from imported products that do not always respect the environmental constraints of the European Union. The goal of relying less on imports is therefore particularly important and necessary. It is just as crucial that our dependence on raw materials is not on one country, but on several, for geopolitical reasons. In particular, this is about cadmium. If we lower the authorized threshold in fertilizers too much, it is to be feared that the list of our supplier countries will be reduced to one. It’s a risk I personally don’t wish to take, and a risk we should avoid, I think. On the same issue of cadmium, the European Union must strike a balance between environmental and health production and economic efficiency. The Commission proposal was far too strict, I think, in this area. Our group is therefore proposing a much more reasonable amendment, which I hope to see supported in the votes soon. Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to remind the Commission in a friendly manner of its role: first of all to protect the European interests of both individuals and professionals. Some companies would thus be strongly impacted by an authorized cadmium threshold that is too low.It is, of course, the jobs that will suffer in the first place.Let the Commission therefore look at what is being done elsewhere!It would be dangerous for the cadmium levels authorized in fertilizers in Europe to become the strictest in the world.I will therefore conclude on this point, which seems essential to me.Of course, the European Union must protect the environment, but it must not disrupt an entire market with a measure which, in addition, will not radically change the quality of the soil.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, a few words about the procedure: I have to honestly confess to you that at the beginning I was an enthusiastic supporter of the procedure, that the committees should have separate responsibilities. I have to say that in the end, looking at this dossier, it would have been better if we had a committee responsible because the committee responsible might ultimately have made it easier for us to find compromises. And I really have to direct the shy criticism of the Environment Committee, which has made a decision, but the key words jobs, geological conditions, raw material security and practicality only marginally interested the Environment Committee. And that's exactly what we suffer from, that's what the discussion is about. Here are two examples. The first example: if you look at the applications - everyone is in favor of defining and limiting the cadmium content, and we also need a European regulation. That's right. We're basically fighting over 40 milligrams. That is the difference. If you do the math: If you really want to improve the soil quality with this difference, you need several hundred years. That would be the same as if someone wanted to change the protein content of their breakfast egg with the salt shaker. Nothing happens there. So I ask a little for objectivity and to look: How is the effect really? The second example: In Central Germany, my region, we have lime deposits. Nobody changed it, God produced it that way, it was put down that way. Lime is a soil conditioner. Lime is used to improve the solubility of nutrients, but the pollutants remain in the soil. We have of course been using this since time immemorial. The scheme proposed by the Commission, supported by the Environment Committee, would lead to that we would close the lime deposits around the corner and then have to transport our lime from a great distance.That is nonsense in itself, and that is why I would ask you to look again at the compromise proposals in the vote tomorrow.Whether 80 or 60 milligrams - that would be a good compromise in the interests of raw material security and in the interests of our farmers.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, I must commend the European Commission, because the proposal is really good. I think my fellow rapporteurs have also done an excellent job, and we are only left with the question of cadmium. There was a lot of talk here about industry, about agriculture, but apart from my colleague Eickhout, few people talked about the health effects. Cadmium is a carcinogen, mutagen, reprotoxin, organotoxin and is accumulative. The health consequences may come ten years after the intoxication occurred. This must be realized first. Food is the main source of cadmium for the European population and it is relatively clear from our agencies that the dietary intake of some groups of cadmium is twice as high as it is tolerable. So it is clear that something needs to be done about it. And for those who are too complicated and discussing here - what is poured into the field is simply there and we eat it, because it is simply not possible to remove cadmium from plants, from those crops, from the resulting food. So the exposure needs to be reduced at source, where the fertilizer is produced. Now let's look at what the Commission is proposing - a limit of sixty milligrams now. There was talk here about how complicated it is to do. There is nothing to do! Today, the average is thirty-four milligrams, for forty milligrams it may be necessary to start mixing a clean source with a dirty one, for twenty milligrams it is necessary to introduce some industrial technologies. In twelve years? In twelve years, friends, we will reach Mars, so hopefully we will be able to clear some fertilizer of contaminants. Many Member States already have these limits, so the debate that agriculture is not competitive with those limits is nonsense. This is proved by the fact that the limits are already there. Please support the Commission's proposal, it is sensible, it is rational, it is achievable and we do not neglect anything else at all.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, my party, NVA, is working hard to make our economy more circular. A level playing field between organic and non-organic fertilizers can strengthen this cycle model. Flanders has been committed to organic recycling for 25 years. In 2015, more than 800,000 tons of the biowaste stream was converted into high-quality compost that I like to call black gold. And 2.2 million tons of other bio-waste streams were also converted into organic fertilizers. Today we can embed these Flemish best practices in European legislation by opting for ambitious European end-of-waste criteria for bio-waste. Bio-waste is a valuable raw material with a lot of economic potential, but today still a third of it is lost in the garbage bag. We have to turn the tide by collecting and recycling bio-waste separately. In this way we can replace a large part of the non-organic fertilizers. My delegation also supports the ambition to reduce cadmium step by step.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I am convinced that the European economy can and must be based on top quality and that only a top product can really survive in the long run as a European product.Therefore, I am convinced that high standards of environmental protection and food safety are a prerequisite for our long-term competitiveness.Today we are talking about what the possibility of choice for the farmer means and I think that in this element there is a way to satisfy all interests in this house because farmers have the right to choose, but we must, I am convinced, encourage those who want maximum protectionenvironment and food safety and, of course, I think we need to encourage technologies and innovation in the agricultural sector.That is the way, I am convinced, we can find a common agreement.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I will not bother with the numbers that have already been said here. The discussion on this proposal for a regulation again shows for whom business interests are more important and who is primarily concerned with human health and environmental protection. The most controversial is, of course, the topic of cadmium limits. This highly dangerous substance poses a serious risk to human health. In addition to the air, it also enters the human body through food. From phosphorus fertilizers it enters the soil and is taken up by plants. It can no longer be removed from them, so we cheerfully consume it in our food. It is a very toxic carcinogen that can contribute to cancer and osteoporosis. This information is publicly known, and yet the right is about to claim an increase in the cadmium limit in fertilizers. This is completely unacceptable. After all, we cannot prefer the profits from the import of low-quality raw materials to human health. I would also point out that the draft regulation omits some other important aspects, such as the addition of a limit for total chromium. The current practice is to add industrial waste to fertilizers, such as waste from the steel or leather industries. Although these are not permitted as component materials for fertilizers, it is nevertheless impossible for control authorities to determine the use of these materials in fertilizers. Biostimulants are a separate chapter. The vast majority of them move in the gray zone, they are pretended to be fertilizers or excipients. We therefore need to change the definition of plant protection products. Most important, however, is the fact that the current situation with missing limits on the risk elements for fertilizers in the European Union is completely unsatisfactory.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we all agree that cadmium content has to be limited – this is not the question we are talking about. The debate here is about the speed and the question of by how much we should reduce it. Seen from this perspective, I find the proposal put forward by the Commission and then changed by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety unacceptable, simply because it goes too far, is far too restrictive and is potentially harmful for EU industrial agriculture.  This is for three reasons. The first has already been mentioned: that there is no scientific evidence that would link the level of cadmium in fertiliser with the level of cadmium in food and crops. There is no solid scientific evidence that the limit of 80 mg or 100 mg leads to the accumulation of cadmium and not to the de—accumulation of cadmium. So we should be careful about making such statements.  The second argument is that the majority of fertiliser plants in Europe import their phosphate rocks from third countries. There is some cadmium content in these raw materials, but a feasible operational decadmiation technology does not exist and this technology cannot simply be developed overnight. So what is the alternative? The alternative would probably be either to go out of business or simply to look for some other sources of supply, but the single readily available source of supply is the Russian Federation. That brings me to the third argument. The third argument is that for phosphate rock, which has been considered by the Commission as a strategic raw material, we do not want to rely on supplies from an unreliable partner. So, if you want to reduce cadmium content and at the same time not destroy our industry, we should think about extending the period of adjustment in order to give our industry time to develop technologies that would fulfil these noble goals as indicated in the Commission proposal. (Applause)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - Mr. president. We are focusing too much on cadmium: it is a very important element, but it is not the only one. It is a regulation that will modify another, fourteen years later; which is also part of the circular economy package, something very important. It is the Regulation that was pending within the circular economy and that will regulate the internal market and will produce harmonization, for the first time - for the first time - in the use of fertilizers. A partial harmonization, it is true, but very, very important. In addition, it will establish conditions for the commercialization of the products and will provide more security in the use of these. I want to say that fertilizers are essential for agricultural productions, but we need fertilizers that are really useful and, therefore, that their effectiveness and agronomic efficiency is demonstrated. This is very important because, for the first time, this Regulation incorporates many new fertilizers: organic fertilizers and mineral or inorganic fertilizers. More than 50% is now outside the regulation. Well, these organic fertilizers are very important within the circular economy, but if we approve in a Regulation organic fertilizers that do not have agronomic efficacy or efficiency, they are not useful for farmers and we will also be polluting. So let's be practical. Cadmium is a substantive element. We all agree to limit the percentages of cadmium, but let's go as far as possible. I think that the Commission has gone much further, and this is not useful, this is not useful for everyone. Nor do I agree to open the nitrates directive, which for my group - as Mr Tarabella has said - is an important issue, and we are not going to allow it, at least with our vote.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
