text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!The Commission's proposal is shocking and absolutely unacceptable.With regard to cadmium limits, European industry currently relies on African raw materials with high cadmium content.Today, in the European Union, limits related to the reduction of cadmium do not exist.It is time to call it a spade: the Commission proposal will result in increased demand for low cadmium deposits.Who will benefit from it?This is the crucial question.Russia will mainly benefit.I am convinced that Putin's colleagues are already rubbing their hands, because you are preparing a really great business for them.Finland, the home country of Commissioner Katainen, will also benefit.The consequence of the Commission's proposal will be, firstly, an increase in the prices of raw materials, production costs, fertilizer prices and, consequently, an increase in food prices.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report is an important report for the future of the industrial and agricultural sector. It covers much broader topics than just the cadmium issue. Unfortunately, discussions crystallized on this issue. I deplore the position of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Indeed, asking for a reduction in the rate in fertilizer to 60 milligrams per kilo now, with the ambition to reach 20 milligrams per kilo in a few years, is absolutely not realistic. It is essential to set objectives, ambitious certainly, but above all accessible in order to give a signal to European SMEs. We must obviously limit the use of inputs in our soils, but this must be done in a pragmatic way. Any measure aimed at reducing the use of mineral fertilizers must be accompanied by research and innovation and must be encouraged. The cadmium issue is a geopolitical issue and this has been said by many of my colleagues before me. So, if we follow the vote of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, we will find ourselves dependent on sources of supply from Russia and Finland. As for the issue of nitrates, I think it is very unwise to open this question. The current legislation is certainly not perfect, but be careful not to open Pandora's box. I think that we must be attentive to the over-transposition of European laws into national laws, which are very often a source of distortion of competition. So, dear colleagues, I invite you, when voting on the Ţurcanu report tomorrow, to be attentive and to consider all the sectors concerned and not only this report from the angle of the cadmium issue.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the efforts of Parliament and the Commission to shift the balance to organic fertilisers while improving the Single Market for fertilisers. In line with the circular economy principle, we need to find an affordable way for our farmers to switch to more organic alternatives. However, since 80% of the EU market is inorganic fertilisers, we have a responsibility to our citizens and the environment to address maximum levels of contaminants in inorganic fertilisers. Cadmium is a Class One carcinogen according to the World Health Organisation, and exposure can lead to pulmonary disorders, kidney disease, cancer, fertility problems and osteoporosis. We have been talking since 2003 of reducing cadmium in fertilisers and it has taken us 14 years to get us to the stage we are at today. I hope in the coming years we will see significantly lower cadmium levels than we see now across the EU and across the world and I welcome these proposals.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - (NL) Mr President, tomorrow we will vote on essential European legislation in the field of the environment and the internal market. The European circular economy must also include fertilising products. We are talking about that here. High-quality mineral concentrate and other organic fertilizer products based on animal manure must be applicable throughout Europe if they have the same efficacy and environmental properties as mineral fertilizers. Phosphate is becoming scarce. Recycling manure and sewage through technology pays off and makes us independent. It is a good signal that this Parliament supports the recovery of struvite and has end-of-manure criteria examined. We must indeed stop the discrimination against high-quality organic fertilizer products based on manure. Our group has therefore tabled another amendment. If you support the circular economy, water quality and European soil health, I am all counting on your support. Throughout Europe, our arable farmers and horticulturists ask for fertilizers, soil improvers and innovative techniques. Let us therefore avoid becoming completely dependent on the phosphate mines of just one country for our food production, and then I am talking about Russia. Because in addition to organic fertilizers, affordable fertilizers are indispensable for our European contribution to food production around the world. Trust our innovative arable farmers, our horticulturalists and fertilizer producers. Finally, we are also always talking about breaking open the nitrates directive. The point is to update outdated legislation, such as the 1991 Nitrates Directive, now hopelessly outdated and unnecessarily obstructing high-quality processed fertilizers. And I look at Mr Tarabella. If you want to achieve what you just mentioned, you will have to agree to this. Otherwise, we will continue to talk, talk, talk in this House and nothing else will get off the ground.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: - Mr President, in fact, this report corrects an anomaly, since organic substances and animal or plant by-products have been used to amend the soil almost since agriculture has existed, but today the internal market only allows circulation of chemical fertilizers. It is therefore an anomaly that has been corrected and a real additional step for the circular economy to now also allow the marking and free circulation of organic fertilizers and plant and animal by-products. On the point that has been the subject of much debate - of course I want to talk about reducing the cadmium level - I am happy that we have set ourselves this target of 20 milligrams per kilo. Here too, I can hear the reluctance of certain colleagues, but I would like us to set a timetable that is a little more ambitious than what could be discussed, since the health of Europeans is at stake. So I invite you tomorrow to be very ambitious on this. And then, if European industry is so precious to you, I also invite you to take its interests into account when talking, for example, of trade defense. It seems to me to be more interesting than putting them in competition with the health of Europeans. But, in any case, these are advances for health and the environment that I invite us to support tomorrow.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, fertilisers are a necessity for producers. In some cases, fertiliser can account for over half of the farmers’ input costs – a price the farmer cannot control. Placing heavy limits on cadmium, despite the lack of scientific evidence to show this is necessary, will reduce supply and hike prices for farmers across the European Union. 80 mg per kilo with provisions to review would still allow risks to public health and the environment to be managed safely. Studies suggest that 80 mg per kilo on average is enough to stop cadmium accumulating in soil. Stronger limits are simply not supported by any available scientific evidence. I would therefore urge Members to support amendments calling for a maximum cadmium level in phosphate fertiliser of 80 mg per kilo.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Each type of fertilization must be balanced. Not only fertilizers of inorganic origin can be a source of over-fertilization, but also organic fertilizers can be a source of over-fertilization. Therefore, we must pay attention to what is rational in this regulation, first of all - that we are turning towards a circular economy, that we want to restore more organic matter to soils, but at the same time we want to use those fertilizers that are intended to good quality. This does not mean that agriculture will give up fertilizers of inorganic origin, that it will only rely on organic fertilizers, because it is impossible due to the intensity of this production. In some departments, only organic fertilizers are the basis of production, because these crops are, after all, on artificial substrates. That is why I want to say that we should strive to circulate as much organic fertilizer as possible, but we also need to take care of the quality of the soil and microorganisms. However, we cannot over-regulate the market. And here, if we introduce these proposals that are related to cadmium, we will make part of our fertilizer sector fall out of the market, because the costs of reclassification to production with a lower content require new technologies, more expensive technologies, in particular when it comes to phosphate from Morocco. . And another alternative source is phosphate rock from Russia or possibly a small amount from Finland. So if we want to move away from monopolizing the raw materials market by only one country, then we should allow a scenario of a reasonable reduction in the cadmium content in fertilizers and then we will achieve this effect, which is related to better quality of fertilizers, with a reduction in pollutants, including cadmium, but we will also obtain that will be reasonable for the industry and also for the farmers who are to use these fertilizers in production.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, European agriculture is called upon to play a leading role in the ever more pressing global challenge of access to food. In this sense, the availability of quality fertilizer products represents one of the conditions for the development of more productive and at the same time more sustainable agricultural models, which in the future must be able to produce more, using fewer inputs. For these reasons, the regulation we are discussing cannot be just an opportunity for harmonization at European level of the rules on traditional fertilizers; on the contrary, it must represent an extraordinary incentive for the production of innovative, effective and low environmental impact products, in total coherence with the circular economy model. The European Parliament's ambitious position must therefore be able to confirm the role of the Union as the leader of sustainable development, while ensuring the availability of fertilising products at fair prices, without creating further distortions of competition to the detriment of our farmers.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, today we are discussing a proposal for European legislation that the European Union fertilizer market needs. The issue that has raised serious concerns, however, is the cadmium content proposed by the Commission at sixty milligrams per kilogram. My colleagues have shown that they have doubts about the existence of a certain scientific basis for the effect of this limit on human health. The Commission's proposal, as it stands, has two negative consequences. First of all, the factories that import phosphates from North Africa, including Romania, do not have the necessary technology to reduce the cadmium content. And here we are not talking about a simple improvement of technology. We talked to the factory in Romania: reducing the cadmium content means completely changing the technological lines in that factory. Secondly, the second negative consequence is that it distorts competition in the European Union economy, in the market for phosphates, phosphate fertilizers, in the sense that the application of this cadmium limit will completely take out of the market factories using raw materials from North Africa. That is why I believe that any measure here must be accompanied by a sufficient number of transitional years to have scientific research that will yield results in this area. Thank you.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, health, food safety and sustainable food production are all important aspects in relation to fertilisers. We have to state that these substances are crucial for agricultural production, but, as in many cases, their overuse can be dangerous. Therefore, the precautionary principle should be first, while mitigation can be realised by smart precision techniques.  I welcome the harmonisation steps between inorganic and organic fertilisers, and also the steps in the field of cadmium levels. Regarding the latter topic, I think that the proposed Commission timeline could be more ambitious, and I would be glad to introduce even lower levels in the EU. There are already existing low cadmium levels, for example in the case of Hungary, where the limit is set at 20%, and everybody is happy. I can imagine that gradually the levels can be reduced.  Because of all these aspects, I am going to support the good results achieved at committee level and also the more ambitious Socialist amendments.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is important to reach a satisfactory agreement that allows the viability of fertilizers on the European market, but without reducing the quality of the products intended for farmers because they are essential products to continue producing food at a low price. reasonable within the Union. Organic fertilizers, although they could be a long-term solution, have not yet proven to be a real option that offers the same demanding standards as mineral fertilizers in terms of their nutrient composition. It is very important to reach a solution for cadmium limits that does not strangle mineral fertilizer producers or increases our dependence on imports from third countries such as Russia, while at the same time being considerate of public health. I would like to emphasize that not all soils are the same in Europe and that not all have the same absorption of cadmium, an aspect that is unfortunately not being taken into account in these negotiations, in which political figures are being considered without scientific foundations. I would like to thank Mrs Gardini here because she has made great efforts on a very difficult matter. And I certainly welcome the amendment that the European People's Group has proposed after having weighed all the interests at stake. I believe that this is a balanced amendment that does not meet anyone's highest aspirations, but it is a way of finding a compromise. I am sorry for the voice with which I am addressing you in plenary, and above all I am sorry that the interpreters have to be listening to me like this, but I am sick.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there has been a lot of talk about this regulation and it is certainly worth it, it is an extremely important regulation. We are stuck at these percentages, but, as the rapporteur has shown and other colleagues have shown, there are improvements through this regulation for the fertilizer market, for the circular economy. However, I would like to point out here that, unfortunately, the Commission did not include in the estimate everything that needed to be included, for example, what impact would it have on jobs? He did not say anything about a study done at the University of the Netherlands in 2016 - here, the findings of this study are relevant, but I am totally in opposition to the arguments used by the Commission. As an IMCO member, of course, I want everything we vote for here to be very well balanced between consumer protection and industry support. Of course, human health is important, but deindustrialization continues. I can't help but say that, unfortunately, if this ambitious percentage is set… Here we are not talking about ambition, we are talking about results, technological research and we cannot impose a threshold over which the industry could not. Therefore, I will support the proposal without a gradual decrease and a proposal of 80 milligrams.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal establishing rules for making CE marked fertilizer products available on the market, covering a wider range of these products and opening up the single market for the free circulation of fertilizer products produced from organic materials or secondary raw materials. If it is true that fertilizers provide relevant benefits in terms of crop yields, it is no less true that we must not forget that there are important environmental, public health and food safety challenges associated with the use of fertilizers. The main objective of the report is to encourage the production of fertilizers on a large scale in the Union, using national organic or secondary raw materials, in accordance with the circular economy model, transforming waste into nutrients for crops. However, the current regulation does not address environmental issues associated with the contamination of soils, inland waters and marine waters and, ultimately, foodstuffs. Cadmium is a sad example of this. Dear colleagues, for all these reasons, I believe that the maximum cadmium limits should be as low as possible in order to provide a high level of protection for human health. And this is what I have to say at the moment.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fertilizer regulation is certainly a step forward. Finally there is a harmonization of the rules, finally the access to the market of innovative fertilizers is facilitated, the use of organic and recycled materials is promoted, finally clearer labels. Unfortunately, there is still no agreement on the limits for cadmium. On cadmium, some colleagues have urged us to be prudent and reasonable. I believe it is unreasonable to minimize or pretend not to know that cadmium is a severely carcinogenic heavy metal that contaminates water, soil and food. I think it is not reasonable to pretend not to know that in many European countries the national limits are lower, in the East and in the West: 20, 22. Italy, which excels in agriculture, has a limit of 50. And then it is possible, we do not propose the moon. We apply the precautionary principle with determination. Dear colleagues, let us not be divided: the proposal we have made is reasonable.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work on this file and on how he has managed the sensitivity of this subject. This initiative does lead to the opening of the single market for the free movement of fertilizers and encourages, in particular, the use of fertilizers from recycled and organic materials, brings safe products for health and also safety standards, more quality, safety and more clarity in labeling. Discussions must continue, however, as there are still discrepancies both at European level and between the European Union and the countries from which we import agricultural or finished products. We want to be ambitious at Union level, as has been said, but at the same time we must take into account the reality in non-EU countries and especially in the Mercosur region, because these discrepancies do not they only create unfair competition within the Union and this will harm European farmers.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a regulation goes in the right direction, by encouraging the large-scale production of organic fertilizers derived from waste, in line with the circular economy model, and by facilitating access to the single market under conditions of parity with traditional inorganic fertilizers. The maximum limits for impurities, such as microbial contaminants, and the new minimum nutrient content per functional category of the product, are also positive, to ensure the quality of CE marked fertilizers. However, more could and should be done to ensure the safety of fertilizers and to reduce limits for heavy metals, particularly cadmium, for each functional category. I think the proposal from the ENVI committee is reasonable and I think that the executive committee is also acceptable, but the compromise put forward - even sixteen years for the reduction of cadmium to 20 milligrams per kilogram of product - I believe it represents more a gift to manufacturers than a serious position and responsible for protecting the environment and consumers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, fertilizers are products for which strict rules are required in order to protect the quality of food, the environment and the health of consumers. And I think that supporting the European fertilizer industry should not be to the detriment of consumer health, so there should definitely be a reduction in cadmium content. I would also like to point out to you, Mr Avramopoulos, that it is necessary to finance a program to denitrify Greek and other European agricultural land. This is something that Greek farmers expect. They want much bigger aid, so that we can really denitrify the Greek land and support, of course, the crops, which will not be to the detriment of the health of the consumers. Finally, it should be noted that, while the import of cheap Bulgarian fertilizers, which do not meet the standards, is prohibited in Greece, the import of products from Bulgaria grown with the banned fertilizers is allowed.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: membre de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, chers collègues, je vous remercie pour ce débat. Je commence par une clarification, cher Marc, en réponse à vos remarques. La Commission ne compte pas et ne souhaite pas rouvrir la directive «nitrates» avec cette proposition, je veux être clair sur ce point. I am confident that the Fertiliser Products Regulation will be really a major contribution to the circular economy in Europe. It will help to turn waste management challenges into economic opportunities for farmers, innovative European technology providers, and manufacturers. It will help us to put more reliance on domestic sources over raw materials that are critical to our agri-industry and it will release agri-chemical manufacturers from many of the regulatory constraints that they are under today. But we must make sure that this new framework does not create new risks. Instead, the regulation must hold manufacturers to account for the safety of their agri-chemicals. At the end of the day, the fertilisers market is a global commodity market, and European manufacturers can compete by adjusting rapidly to the high level of protection that the European farmers and citizens rightly expect. I look forward to your continued support and to constructive discussions on how to strike the right balance.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu
text: rapporteur.- Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened with great interest to everything that has been said here today, and I want to assure you that I will take into account all the recommendations that have come.The important thing now is that tomorrow's result will be a good one, and in the negotiations, as I said, I will take this into account.My role is to try to find a common denominator between Member States that have different positions on limiting cadmium levels, a hot topic in this case.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, October 24, 2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - Completing the common market for crop enhancers will improve the competitiveness of European agriculture and provide an opportunity to set a common health minimum in the EU. However, economic recovery cannot be the sole goal. We need to keep in mind not only the workers directly affected by the regulation, but all those who are indirectly involved in the issue. In this case, it is a very important group: every single European citizen who consumes the food produced here every day. The most controversial point in the report is the cadmium levels in phosphate-containing fertilizers. Cadmium is a toxic substance for the human body that accumulates in the human body and above a certain level causes severe damage and cancer. It is in the common interest of all of us to keep cadmium pollution through fertilizers below critical levels, even if this move leads to a deterioration in the competitiveness of polluting plants. Hungarian regulations are strict and forward-looking on the issue of cadmium. The gradual reduction of cadmium levels proposed by the European Commission and approved by the European Parliament at the level of the commission prescribes the adjustment to the current Hungarian level. This is the right direction and I cannot support a proposal that multiplies carcinogens in the food consumed by the Hungarian population.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. - Colleagues, we have before us an amendment to the Fertilizer Products Directive, which emphasizes stricter protection of soil resources and the environment. It introduces and reduces permitted limits for heavy metals such as cadmium, arsenic and chromium, and for pathogens. It also introduces biostimulants and enables the production of CE fertilizers from processed agricultural waste, such as manure or compost, thus reducing dependence on phosphates imported into the EU from third countries. Modification of the Nitrates Directive is also important for the use of manure. Better use of waste and returning substances to the cycle is not only a logical step for a good manager, but also an opportunity for innovation and new technological processes. At the same time, however, a solution needs to be found that strikes a balance between environmental protection, phosphorite dependence and fertilizer efficiency. I appreciate the reduction of administrative burdens and voluntary harmonization - it is enough for manufacturers to comply with national regulations. However, I do not agree with the inclusion of mulching films in the scope of the directive.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the offenses and penalties applicable to illicit drug trafficking [10537/1/2017 - C8-0325 / 2017- 2013/0304 (COD)] Rapporteur Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (A8-0317 / 2017) and report by Michał Boni, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Councilamending Regulation (EC) No1920/2006 on the exchange of information, the early warning system and the risk assessment procedure for new psychoactive substances [COM (2016) 0547 - C8-0351 / 2016 - 2016/0261 (COD)] (A8-0359 /2016)

name: Michał Boni
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, it took three years to achieve the final version of the new psychoactive substances solution with the Council. We have overcome the deadlock thanks to efforts by all partners, especially the Maltese Presidency. Why is this so important? Six hundred and twenty-eight new psychoactive substances were formally notified by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) in 2016 as dangerous for life and health, of which 100 were notified for the first time; 560 substances are now monitored. There were 254 victims of new psychoactive substances who died in EU in 2016 and 2017. In my country – Poland – alone, nearly 3000 citizens were poisoned by new psychoactive substances from January to August this year. So it is a real challenge. New psychoactive substances are so readily accessible because of the new digital channels and lack of clear rules. It is a cross-border phenomenon, so our responses must be cross-border – European. It is our moral and political obligation to act. Together, all Member States and our partners, as well as local authorities and NGOs, must act with determination to protect the health of our citizens, especially the young generation. And they must act as fast as possible, using scientific knowledge to build an early warning system and proper risk assessment arrangements – which are crucial for banning dangerous substances – coordinating far more effectively the measures taken by particular countries, using best practices, promoting the understanding of all threats related to the drugs and new psychoactive substances, giving the proper tools to the EMCDDA and supporting its organisational and financial capability. The new procedure in the regulation will be as follows. Member States will ensure that the national focal points of the drugs network and of Europol provide the necessary information on the new psychoactive substances to the EMCDDA and Europol. The EMCDDA shall gather, together with Europol, all this information and communicate it to Member States and the Commission. If there is a suspicion that the new psychoactive substance may pose health or social risks at EU level, the EMCDDA, the Commission or a majority of Member States can ask the EMCDDA to draft an initial report. The initial report shall give the first indication of the nature and scale of incidents, the chemical and physical description of the substance and the involvement of criminal groups in its manufacture. The report has to be prepared within five weeks. If the initial report indicates that the substance may pose severe risks, the Commission requests that EMCDDA prepare a risk assessment report, which should include more in-depth analysis. This will be done by the Scientific Committee of EMCDDA in six weeks. If the risk assessment report shows that the substance poses severe risks, the Commission prepares the delegated act to include this substance on the list of drugs. Member States have to ban this substance as soon as possible, but within six months at the latest. So, as a result, we are shortening the procedure by well over a year, we will have more common European actions, a more precise risk assessment model and an early warning system. This regulation will be a complement to the European Union drugs strategy and is necessary to protect our citizens.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio
text: speaker. - Mr. president. According to the latest European Report on Drugs 2017, presented by the European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction, deaths from overdoses have increased considerably due to a lack of knowledge about the dangerousness of these new psychoactive substances. In 2015, there were among the 28 EU Member States, plus Norway and Turkey, a total of 8,441 overdose deaths, mostly related to heroin and other drugs. The most widely used illegal stimulant drugs in Europe are cocaine, ecstasy and amphetamines. In my country, Spain, a total of 455 drug-induced deaths were registered in 2015 - 15 per million inhabitants, compared to the community average of 21.3 per million citizens. Apart from the conventional drugs that I have already mentioned - such as cocaine and heroin - the use of new psychoactive substances is increasing every year. In June this year, Commissioner Avramopoulos expressed his concern for young people, who are exposed to new and dangerous substances. These new legal psychoactive substances, also known as designer drugs, are a group of synthetic or semi-synthetic chemical compounds that are produced in industrial laboratories, most of them in China or India, and that are circulating in a legal market. The popularity of these substances has been increasing in Europe and the rest of the world due to their availability on the Internet and because they are easily sold in stores. Every year, many young people - particularly men - die from using new psychotropic substances. The European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction in Lisbon detected 540 new psychotropic drugs in the Union last year, and the trend continues to increase every year. The growth of the sale on the Internet of these types of drugs and the ease of production have made it more difficult for the Union Europe can stop its production. The 2014 Framework Decision was no longer effective; therefore, a new legislative instrument was necessary. The Commission drew up a new Regulation in 2013 - Mr Boni is the rapporteur for the report on that Regulation - and, as a consequence, a new Directive to overcome this legal challenge. Almost five years later, we have finally reached an agreement. The aim of the legislative package is to reduce the availability of risky new psychoactive substances, which will be done through faster and more effective action at Union level compared to the instrument we had, from 2005, which did not include information exchange, early warning, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances. The Directive, in particular, has aimed to amend Framework Decision 757/2004 in order to criminalize new psychotropic substances. From now on, Member States can take the necessary measures to ensure that those who manufacture it, those who produce it and those who distribute it - this designer drug - are punished with maximum sentences of five to ten years of deprivation of liberty. I have to remember that this directive does not criminalize the consumption, but the trafficking of this drug. These two instruments - Directive and Regulation - have come a long way. Parliament approved the proposal in 2014 but, until today, we have not been able to find a satisfactory compromise. Both reports are a success, as we have reached an agreement that will help all European citizens. I would finally like to thank the Maltese Presidency for its excellent work in finding a balance between Parliament and the Council. I also want to thank the Commission for its supportive role during all the trilogue meetings. And finally, I would like to express my gratitude to Mr Boni for the very fruitful cooperation that We have carried out.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, our debate today is of great importance for our society, and especially our youth, who are our future. None of us here today can ignore this longstanding and continuously evolving threat affecting, directly or indirectly, the lives of millions of citizens in Europe. More than 93 million Europeans have tried an illicit drug in their lives. Overdose deaths continue to rise. As the Commissioner responsible, I am fully committed to the fight against this threat, which cuts across all generations. Despite, as you know, my particularly heavy obligations and responsibilities in tackling the migration crisis and threats to our security, the fight against drugs – I can assure you – is a key priority for me. Today we are proving once more that Europe is not just about numbers. Europe has a social face, it cares about those in need and it works hard to crack down on unscrupulous criminal networks and their unethical businesses. Drugs is one of these. I would like warmly to welcome the successful conclusion, after four years, of the intense and demanding interinstitutional negotiations on the New Psychoactive Substances Package. This result would not have been possible without the great contribution of the two rapporteurs, Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Michal Boni. I would like to thank both of them personally for their constant efforts and support, and their commitment. In addition to traditional illicit drugs, the number of new and very harmful substances being placed on the European market, often as legal alternatives, is dramatically increasing. Our European Drugs Agency is currently monitoring more than 620 new psychoactive substances that cause severe health problems or even death. In fact, one new psychoactive substance is detected every week. Once the new legislation enters into force, we will leave behind lengthy procedures and will put in place an effective and efficient tool to tackle harmful new psychoactive substances. Information exchanges will improve and the role of the European Drugs Agency will be enhanced, including by working hand-in-hand with Europol. So far, the European Union has banned 19 new psychoactive substances and eight more are in the process of being banned. I would like to thank you in advance for adopting your opinion tomorrow on a concrete case of a very dangerous new psychoactive substance, furanylfentanyl, which must be made subject to control measures. Today’s package is part of a wider, comprehensive approach that this Commission has been working on for the past three years, in the context of the EU drugs strategy, in order to support Member States’ efforts in the fight against drugs. In July, the Council adopted the EU Drugs Action Plan for the period 2017 to 2020, on the basis of my proposal. This action plan enhances and updates existing actions, while it also identifies new priority areas such as online awareness-raising activities, targeting young people in particular, and exploring the potential connection between drug trafficking and the financing of terrorist groups, migrant smuggling and trafficking in human beings. We are also working very actively on the new policy cycle on organised and serious crime, towards disrupting activities related to drug production, trafficking and distribution in the European Union. The EU is also in the lead in the worldwide fight against drugs, together with its global partners. For the first time, the Union is speaking with one voice on drugs-related issues in international forums. We hope this will also be the case at the next meeting of the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs. Obviously our fight against drugs is not finished with this legislation, but today we are sending a clear and strong message about our decisiveness and readiness to tackle new and very dangerous threats to our society. We must and we will continue our efforts in close and continuing cooperation with this House, the Member States and stakeholders. I am looking forward to the debate today and I thank you for the attention you are giving to European drugs policy.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate Ms Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Mr Boni on their very good reports. As rapporteur for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a regulation as regards information exchange, early warning systems and risk assessment, I confronted a harsh reality. There has been a rapid increase in the past years in the number and type of new psychoactive substances available and launched on the European drug market, with more than 600 substances being monitored by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs. Of even more concern than this is the unprecedented increase in substance use among young people, which is really very worrying. I have stated, in the Environment Committee opinion, that the rapid growth of the market in these novel products makes it necessary to enhance monitoring and early warning systems so as to assess health, safety and social risks, in order to develop responses. Member States need to provide, without undue delay, all available information on detection and identification, use and patterns of use, prevalence of use, potential as well as identified risks and commercial, as well as medical and scientific, use of these substances.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, the constant development and availability of new psychoactive substances poses a significant threat in the fight against drugs. It is therefore appropriate for the European Union's internal market to respond to this innovation in the field of drug development. I see the problem especially in synthetic hemp, where producers change the composition of the substance slightly after the ban on a certain substance and thus the chemical formulas are constantly changing. This allows the re-availability of a psychoactive substance on the market in one of the member countries, in so-called smart shops. These are dangerous substances on which addiction can be developed, especially among adolescents. An efficient and effective exchange of information on these substances between Member States based on an early warning and risk assessment system is therefore highly desirable. I appreciate the provision of information between the various institutions without undue delay, for example between the European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction and Europol. I also appreciate the extension to assess not only the health but also the safety risks associated with new psychoactive substances. Also, given that the degree of similarity in the chemical structures of new psychoactive substances is often difficult to determine, the Center should have the power to determine whether certain substances can be considered sufficiently similar. The aim of both the regulation and the directive is to support member states in the fight against drug trafficking. While respecting subsidiarity, the experience of experts and the exchange of information at European level must also be used to combat the drug business, which threatens the citizens of the European Union, more effectively. That is why I thank the European Commission and the two rapporteurs for their persistent work and I believe that it will be supported.

name: Anna Hedh
text: for the S&D group. - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for their very good cooperation and Commissioner Avramopoulos for his contribution to the debate. Together, despite the fact that the Member States have run out of time, we have now brought this legislation to fruition. The number of new psychoactive substances continues to increase in Europe and causes deaths. About 600 substances are now in EU databases, and there is no indication that the problem will decrease. Unscrupulous criminals sell the substances, sometimes under misleading terms and in uncontrolled doses. The result is potentially life-threatening substances, which can be bought by anyone. Of course, the issue is addressed in the Member States, and good things are being done at national level, but for criminal groups not only to be able to change Member States, European cooperation is required. Shared databases and knowledge are necessary to be able to more quickly identify new substances and get solid information about their negative health effects. What then does the new legislation add? In particular, the package will simplify the procedure at EU level to assess the possible negative effects of a new psychoactive substance. A decision on a possible ban can be made more quickly. The procedure will now be almost twice as fast as before. In addition, the new provisions will further reduce the time available to Member States to implement the EU decision from twelve to six months. Finally, the package will hopefully improve the exchange of information, not least between relevant EU authorities, in the early warning and risk assessment system at EU level. All of this is extremely important. The faster we can identify a substance and take action, the less spread. Time is an important factor and in the long run it is a matter of life and death. I welcome the adoption of this package tomorrow and call on all Member States to make full use of these instruments.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, colleagues, psychoactive substances are imitation drugs that have a significant negative effect on public health. For example, there is the substance acryl fentanyl - a mouthful - a substance that is 50 times stronger than morphine. Since the summer of 2016, that substance has claimed 40 victims. Despite this, Chinese producers just keep selling it online. It is also legal in some Member States. Over the past ten years, the number of variants of psychoactive substances at European level has increased enormously. For example, in 2015, a new substance was notified in the EU early warning system on average every three days. The problem is that the current European system is outdated, because it only focuses on classic drugs. Moreover, it does not allow for rapid action, hence the proposal for a directive to be voted on tomorrow. Under the new directive, counterfeit drugs will no longer be excluded from the common European approach to the fight against drugs, with the ultimate aim of preventing problems arising in police and judicial cooperation in the Union. The new directive significantly shortens the timeframes for rapid and effective action, making the EU early warning system much more efficient. Everyone agrees that dangerous designer drugs should be banned and removed from the market. But today any dangerous substance that Europe wants to ban has to go through a cumbersome legislative procedure. In this way, valuable time is always lost. Tomorrow, for example, Parliament has to give its opinion on the substance furanylfentanyl. Dealers, meanwhile, are given free rein. People become seriously ill or even die. And when the substance in question is eventually banned, a new variant will already be on the market. This is how we fight against the quay. We want to put an end to this with these rules. It is high time for the to tackle harmful drugs that make big money.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I want to congratulate, first of all, Mrs Jiménez-Becerril, for her work, and also Mr Boni, the Commission and all those who have spoken before me because I fundamentally share everything they have said. In fact, it is repeating talking about the detection of so many psychotropic substances that we have, on the one hand, to attend to, evaluate and prevent them from being on the market, although part of what we have to do is educational. In the 80s, I was able to see how several young people in my environment became schizophrenic or had psychotic attacks due to the psychotropic drugs that existed at that time and how others died after their addiction to heroin. There is a part of what we have to do that is reflective and a part that we have to do that, of course, has to do with education, because the figures we are talking about are not figures, they are people: broken lives, abandonment school, family and social tragedies, severe poisonings, health complications —as I have already said— mental or physical, and also the death of adolescents who are almost children. So the argument for more effective and proportionate detection and alert action on these substances is absolutely necessary. We from the Liberal Group consider it very opportune that the early warning mechanism on this type of new substances has been reviewed, given the rapid evolution of which we are talking and the increasing danger among children --practically adolescents, they are almost children— who have the possibility of obtaining these drugs on the internet, with great accessibility, without knowing the risks and dangers. We believe that there is a need for greater cooperation by Europol with the European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction and the European Medicines Agency. We have to go together in this because the problem goes beyond national capacities and we must help overcome fragmentation, obstacles and legal uncertainties.We have been waiting for this package of measures since 2013, so we hope that there will be no more delays and that we can contribute a lot, fighting very little and never again for the interpretation of trivialities between the institutions.We need this legislation.

name: João Ferreira
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the exchange of information between Member States, the existence and functioning of an early warning system and the risk assessment procedures for new psychoactive substances are of great importance. The European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction will currently monitor more than 450 substances. In recent years, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number, type and availability of psychoactive substances, a reality that coincides with the persistence of a deep and drawn-out social crisis, with very significant levels of unemployment, poverty and social exclusion, with the continued attack on social and labor rights, with the weakening of public services. In order to intervene in this complex reality, a comprehensive approach is recommended, integrating the aspects of prevention, deterrence, risk reduction and minimization of damage, up to treatment and social reintegration. It is necessary to deepen the knowledge about a rapidly changing reality, both in terms of substances, consumption habits and their prevalence in different groups of the population. It is necessary to identify the constraints in access to the health care delivery system and to expand, diversify and properly equip the public service network in the area of ​​drug addiction, privileging a proximity response. A path that requires confronting and reversing the effects of public spending cuts policies that are being imposed by the European Union on Member States.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! There has been a record increase in the number, type and availability of new psychoactive substances on the European drug market. Michał Boni and others have already addressed the large amount of substances currently under surveillance in the system, but the problem is that we are seeing a steady increase. The new psychoactive substances are a major challenge for public health because they produce similar effects as the traditional drugs but are not yet drug-classified. These so-called online drugs are easy to buy for anyone over the internet. Some of these strong psychoactive substances have many serious and sometimes fatal consequences and are unfortunately used by many young people in parts of Europe as cheap drugs. They are perceived as relatively safe and legal alternatives to the established illegal drugs. It is estimated that EU citizens spend over € 24 billion on illicit drugs each year, that at least 6,800 people died from overdoses in the EU in 2014 and that an estimated 17.8 million young adults have used drugs in the past year. The human and social costs of drug use are very high. This requires a faster and more effective common system than today, in order to limit the availability of such drugs in our societies. We therefore welcome the agreement that the institutions have now finally reached on the new legislative package, which aims to significantly speed up the procedure at EU level with regard to risk assessment and decisions on control measures. We also support the decision to leave the legal basis to public health - we think it is more natural - instead of the internal market, and we are in favor of the more scientific approach in the proposals when investigating the different effects of new substances. As I said, the negotiations have been going on for more than four years now and we have no more time to lose. We need to act urgently, efficiently and coordinated.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, combating the distribution of illegal drugs is a global issue that requires all countries to cooperate in order to effectively fight. How best to tackle this issue is, however, up for debate. Some countries have chosen to take a softer approach, whereas others – most notably the Philippines – enact a zero—tolerance policy on drugs. The EU, however, decides that the best way to tackle illegal drugs is via legislation. And whilst this may appear to show the EU taking the issue of drugs seriously, it fails to tackle the fundamental problems that facilitate the drug issues in the EU – that, of course, being the borderless Schengen area.  A Europe without borders not only facilitates the free movement of drugs, but also the free movement of weapons, terrorists, and illegal migrants. If the EU wishes to take the protection of its citizens seriously, it must dismantle Schengen, and it must dismantle it straight away. (Applause)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, it is a fact that drugs are a scourge of modern society, which is why all states, both nationally and internationally, are trying to identify drugs, to detect them, to limit their trafficking, to curb the addiction of young people to them and impose penalties on traffickers and traffickers. Unfortunately, all these measures only address the consequences of drug trafficking. If we want to tackle the problem on its basis and decisively, states must strengthen the institution of the family. This will help to educate children properly, in a healthy environment, not to have psychological problems and not to feel the need to resort to artificial drug paradises. Schools need to educate young people about the devastating effects of drug use. The state must also take care to eliminate youth unemployment, so that they are not forced to become addicted to drugs and become slaves to traffickers and traffickers. Finally, states as well as the European Union, as an international organization, must protect the lives of their citizens and conflict with the interests of international drug cartels, no matter how powerful, and impose death sentences on traffickers and traffickers. .

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing one of the tragedies of our time: the use and addiction of psychotropic substances that threaten the health and lives of millions of people.This theme crosses the existential drama of young people and adults, it threatens their mental equilibrium, it becomes an occasion for malfeasance and illicit trafficking.The number of substances is growing dramatically and therefore it seems to me that the decision to strengthen the control and alarm system, making it even more widespread, accompanying the control systems with research on the effects and outcomes of the increasingly frequent usealso of mix of substances.Finally, and I come back to this issue again, the internet marketing of psychoactive substances should be strictly prohibited, because it is accessible to everyone and because it is also, perhaps, cheaper.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, psychoactive substances and their precursors have never been produced and distributed globally at a faster rate than today. Greater availability of knowledge and modern technologies, in addition to all its positive effects, has brought abuses such as its use in the production and distribution of drugs. We must stop these abuses, but not by limiting the availability of knowledge and technology, but on the contrary, using them to develop smart and effective policies and advanced systems to fight organized crime. This proposal before us today is of exceptional quality because it establishes an appropriate and effective framework for early detection, rapid notification and elimination of new psychoactive substances from the European market, without compromising the principle of subsidiarity. This constructive approach should also be applied in bilateral relations with third countries, which often represent the source of new psychoactive substances and their precursors, in order to stop this evil already at its source.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, for the past 50 years, governments have thrown billions, even trillions, of dollars, pounds and even euros at the so-called war on drugs, and all it has resulted in is more ways for the drug traffickers and drug cartels to put different substances on the streets. And now we get these psychoactive substances. In my constituency, you go down some streets and you find these little gas canisters on the street. Legislation like this – legislation like any in the war on drugs – is always reactive. You’re trying to put the toothpaste back in the tube: you’re trying to stop something that is already happening, and by the time you have stopped it another substance is on the street, another legal high. Unless you recognise and look at the social problems behind it, unless you realise that throwing more money, more money and more money at the war on drugs is not working, unless new ways are found, then you are just going to be wasting taxpayers’ money that could be spent on healthcare, education or defence, or on combating the problems and the criminality associated with drugs, but not necessarily addressing the drug problem itself.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr President, anti-ban policy has failed just because in the Netherlands and the Czech Republic cannabis use exceeds 50% of students, even 13-year-olds, while in Greece it is only 9% according to the European Monitoring Center. The monopolies of the monopoly groups for the promotion of the anti-prohibition campaign testify to the desire to convince the people that, not only do drugs not harm, but they also have healing properties. In fact, without formal research on usefulness and side effects. The SYRIZA-ANEL government with the so-called "medical cannabis" as a Trojan Horse aims at Greece in the legalization and release of drugs. The European Union is now proposing a new "add-on" from the list of illegal substances, which hides a bazaar of big interests. Coordination measures are the other side of the stalemate in governments' stalemate. Drugs are not a free choice. It is a coercion of the class, exploitative society that must be overthrown. Not in all drugs. Whole life, not in doses.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteurs of the two dossiers we are debating today, with which the European legislative framework on the fight against drugs is updated, criminalizing the illegal trade in new psychoactive and psychotropic substances. The subjecting of the illicit trafficking of these new substances to provisions of criminal law certainly constitutes a deterrent, also aimed at placing limits on the availability and consumption of substances that are sometimes extremely dangerous for the health of our young people. However, alongside repressive interventions, it is necessary to prepare prevention and information measures precisely on the harmful effects deriving from the use of new psychoactive substances. Coordinated actions must therefore be put in place between Member States to harmonize substantive national legislation and, of course, as rightly supported by the proposed regulation, to ensure the fastest exchange of information on new substances that could be classified as psychoactive.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteurs on the drugs package. New psychoactive substances are a relatively new phenomenon and Europe was the first to move in this direction. However, today the phenomenon must be considered as a global phenomenon and it is necessary to respond quickly to new challenges with new measures. We certainly cannot be satisfied with the silence that has been there so far; Silence with respect to some international events, such as the ministerial meeting at the United Nations in 2019 to assess whether the international community has eliminated or significantly reduced the cultivation, demand, production, trafficking and recycling of drugs, is not acceptable. We cannot ignore society, which asks us to discuss openly and without taboos about cannabis derivatives, a substance that engages our law enforcement agencies for 80% of its resources. Among other things, the legalization of cannabis would make it possible to remove a market that generates a turnover of 9.3 billion a year from organized crime. Too often, the important pharmacological properties of this substance have also been underestimated. I therefore believe it appropriate to launch an open debate in the coming months in Parliament on the role of the Union in the UN and on the need to give cannabis a status that is more in step with the times.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as a result of the debate so far, we needed to come up with such a proposal. The Commission is very pleased that it came up with such a proposal. I think the statistics motivate this. In the last ten years, there has been a massive increase in new psychoactive substances both globally and in Europe. And, unfortunately, there is no sign of slowing down. In the last five years, 70% of new substances placed on the market have been discovered. There is a clear need for the European Union to act on new psychoactive substances. Member States, individually, cannot control the problems caused by the spread of new substances. Uncoordinated national actions in this area can have negative domino effects, such as the movement of harmful substances from one Member State to another. Criminal groups could take advantage of this situation and the worst thing is that young people are attracted here. Young people fall into the trap the easiest. There is obviously a need for better collaboration, for the exchange of information between the European Monitoring Center for Drugs, Europol and the European Medicines Agency, but there is also a need for a concern for the education of young people.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the past five years there has been an unprecedented increase in the number, type and availability of new psychoactive substances in Europe, with over 100 new drugs identified for the first time. The World Health Organization states that the new psychoactive substances available in Europe are particularly dangerous due to toxicity, interaction with other substances and influence on mental processes. The rapid increase of new psychoactive substances constitutes a new challenge for the definition of an effective control policy against the use of these substances, in which the European Union must be at the forefront, both through the coordination action of Europol and through the EU rapid alert system, an essential tool because it is able to allow national authorities to identify new substances and act promptly to intercept and remove them from the market. A joint effort by the European institutions is therefore necessary, an economic, logistical and political effort, so that national and community authorities are equipped with adequate tools to combat the spread and development of new drugs, which are increasingly difficult to identify and unfortunately increasingly dangerous. .

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, always and everywhere, but really always and everywhere, I will do everything to remove drugs, to make drugs disappear because it does not need to be repeated much, how evil it is for humanity, how evil it is especially for young people.Unfortunately, I also have bad experiences.Some of my acquaintances, acquaintances left because of an overdose.But I also have positive experiences.Istria's experience at a lower level, not at the world, not at the European, not at the national level, can help because there are good examples of the fight against drug abuse, coordinated actions of repressive bodies, but also educational, educational institutions and health institutions when we already have addicts.Honest conversations with addicts can help, but it is up to us to try to effectively prevent all this from happening because the rapid growth of drugs is unfortunately something we are witnessing today.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is fairly obvious that, if there was no prohibition on the consumption of cannabis, the synthetic forms of cannabis would disappear from the market in the same way that the demand for melted—down boot polish plummeted after the repeal of prohibition of alcohol in the US. The choice we must make is that of allowing access to a relatively benign plant, which has had many, many studies carried out on it, or leave our young people to the mercy of a legal, untested cocktail of chemicals. In Ireland alone, in the region of 100 000 people have a criminal record for possession of cannabis. It prevents them from travelling, from parenting and from access to decent employment. The law, rather than the drug, destroys their lives. This is the main reason why young people take these dangerous cocktails of drugs. The alternative is to face a life of ruin for taking a safer substance called cannabis. The war on drugs is a war on people. It must end. Start it by legalising cannabis now.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the report is welcome, but its results are late and incomplete. A stated pursuit is a drug-free society, not a lax passive approach with theoretical measures to reduce the harmful effects of use. The slowness of response, the replacement of controlled substances with legitimate, uncontrolled alternatives, and the practically repressive goals of a comprehensive anti-drug policy call for a uniform, general and flexible extension of definitions. Preventive, valid information of the citizens, the supportive treatment of the users as patients and the strict application of criminal measures are required at all stages until the disposal. In addition, the absolute restriction of any substance in terms of production, any trafficking and possession with the intention of disposal must be adopted, so that it is consumed for its psychotropic properties with a few appropriate exceptions on the basis of already implemented programs.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, once again I would like to express my thanks to the European Parliament, and in particular to our two rapporteurs for their constructive work over the past year on this very important topic. As has been said today, we need a strong response to the phenomenon of the number of new drugs being detected at EU level. We need – and, again it is something we will work on – swift, strong action to protect Europeans, in particular our youth and those who are vulnerable in our societies, from the extremely dangerous threat of harmful new psychoactive substances. The proposed EU legislation will improve the speed of our action against these substances, enabling us to act even within weeks in the case of an immediate risk to public health. It also ensures that an effective process for exchange of information is in place, and that our European Drugs Agency has the competences and the resources to provide the relevant expert advice. A long process in Parliament and in the Council is coming to a successful end, but the fight against drugs does not end here. We have a lot of work ahead. We have taken some important steps but there is still much to do: firstly to protect our youth, as I have said, and also to support the victims and to prosecute the criminals. The Commission and I, personally, will stand by our Member States in tackling this sensitive issue. I count on your support and I am looking forward to an overwhelming majority for this important package in tomorrow’s vote.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio
text: speaker. - Mr. President, from here today we are sending a clear message about the need to penalize new psychotropic drugs because I believe that 540 new drugs a year are not something that we should underestimate, because the lives of our young people are at risk and it is our duty as Legislators no longer ignore this very serious threat. We cannot continue in this legal limbo in which we have been until now. Really, to me, spending five years processing this seems a shame; I think we really should have done it much faster. Finally, as I have already said and thanks to the Maltese Presidency, we have streamlined the process, but it has cost us blood, sweat and tears. I think our young people and the threat and risk that these new psychotropic drugs pose for young people needed much more agility. So, thanks to all the parliamentarians, I think we have seen here that we are all in the same boat. I think it is necessary to penalize these drugs because, although there has also been talk of not penalizing them, I think not, I think the problem with these drugs is ignorance about their dangerousness - our young people do not know, because there is no information about this -; when they begin to be penalized, the path of criminals will become much more difficult, as the commissioner has said. I think we have to be faster than them. Therefore, today we have taken a big step, but of course we are going to take many more, and I want to thank Mr Boni, the commissioner, my assistants, the advisors and all those who have worked during these five years to ensure that tomorrow the result of this vote is favorable. I am sure that it will, because it is what we have seen here today.

name: Michał Boni
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, again I would like to thank Teresa Jiménez and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation. Commissioner, special thanks are due to the Commission because the Commission helped us to solve many problems, so thank you very much again. And thank you very much to all participants in this discussion because I think that it was very multi-dimensional. The debate focused on many issues but the goal is clear: to restrict access to new psychoactive substances and drugs and understand how important this cooperation among all institutions – the EMCDDA, Europol, Member States – is in order, on the one hand, to fight against criminal organisations and punish the sale, distribution and production of those substances and, on the other, to halt the spread of those substances all over Europe. The second key point raised during the discussion is the problem of awareness. It would be a very good opportunity when we start implementation of the directive and the regulation for the EMCDDA to do more, in cooperation with all countries, to raise awareness about new psychoactive substances and drugs and make those issues much more understandable for all social groups, especially the younger generation. The last point is related to proper implementation, because having a good legislative framework and good cooperation is important, but we need to combine all such measures properly: legislation, cooperation between all institutions and awareness-raising.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 24 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is estimated in official EU reports that in Europe there is a cocaine market of about 124 tonnes, worth about USD 34 billion, an increased use of narcotic drugs and higher health risks. It is clear that the criminal networks behind the illicit drug traffic demonstrate a resilient ability to adapt and diverge their modus operandi in order to make a widespread of drug use. In the cyclical search for drug supply and trafficking, criminal acts vary from funding with illicit capital to use of the latest technology to avoid being intercepted, and finally to money laundering.  Therefore, in order to combat illicit drug trafficking, the following actions are imperative: increase the criminal penalties; implement harsher laws for selling and buying drugs; and enhance international cooperation between authorities on drug trafficking, money laundering and tax evasion. I am confident that as we move forward by increasing international cooperation and by raising awareness of the health risks and legal consequences for the illicit drug trafficking, we will succeed in the field of illicit drug trafficking.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing.- The world of drugs is a rapidly changing world that is increasingly threatening the physical and mental health of our children and young people.Drug traffickers are now present around our schools, where young people themselves can access these drugs more and more easily.An integrated approach can only be taken in the fight against drugs: prevention, rehabilitation and law enforcement are also essential.Every effort should be made to provide young people, teachers and parents with adequate information.Furthermore, it is essential that synthetic drugs, which are perhaps the most toxic, be added to the list of banned drugs as quickly as possible.All time lost in human life can be measured in this area.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of the report by Virginie Rozière, on behalf of the Legal Affairs Committee, on Reasonable Measures to Protect Whistleblowers in the public interest when disclosing confidential information held by businesses and public authorities (2016/2224 (INI)) (A8-0295 / 2017).

name: Virginie Rozière
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, when we present a job like this, it is customary to thank colleagues for the work accomplished. I would happily do that, but I wanted to start by thanking other people. Say thank you to Antoine Deltour, thank you to Raphaël Halet, thank you to Irène Frachon, thank you to Denis Robert, thank you to all those who, one day, make this courageous choice which is to speak. This is never an easy choice because, for whistleblowers, it is making the choice of truth, making the choice of ethics, making the choice of the general interest, and this is very often a choice that is made at its own risk. I also wanted to stress that this is the first time that this Parliament has adopted a text on the protection of whistleblowers. This is quite surprising, because other institutions have already adopted resolutions on this subject; I am thinking, in particular, of the Council of Europe, which adopted a resolution in 2014, which sets ambitious and high objectives, objectives on which we have, moreover, based our work. I spoke of Antoine Deltour and Raphaël Halet, and I also wanted to underline that, on the other hand, this Parliament has often called for the protection of whistleblowers and that this has often been part of the resolutions which followed the LuxLeaks case. I am thinking of the reports of the TAX 1 and TAX 2 special committees. So, yes, we thanked Antoine Deltour and Raphaël Halet, we even thanked Antoine Deltour with the European citizen award. We took action to fight tax evasion thanks to him - thanks to them - but today Antoine Deltour and Raphaël Halet have been given suspended prison sentences. So we are moving forward, we are working and improving the daily lives of European citizens in the fight against tax evasion, but they are still condemned. It is particularly important today that this Parliament calls for an instrument to be adopted to protect whistleblowers in Europe. In this text, we lay down a framework that can serve as a basis for effective protection. In particular, we propose a broad definition of whistleblowers, considering that we must not focus on a particular situation - employees, subcontractors, consultants -, but rather on the nature of the information that is revealed, and therefore consider that from the moment a whistleblower discloses information on acts contrary to the general European interest, at that time, he must be protected. Precisely, what protection for whistleblowers? We know that, very often, when we speak, we are subjected to a lot of pressure, even to reprisals. It is therefore a matter of making it clear that such reprisals are punishable under criminal law and ensuring that they are punished and that the damage caused to whistleblowers and their entourage is fully remedied. We also want whistleblowers to be able to receive financial legal support when needed. We see that in many cases they have to face extremely degraded living conditions, a job lost, a house sold, resources reduced to a minimum. This is why we must also be able to provide financial support in certain cases, but also psychological help, because each time it is a test to be confronted with organizations which, for their part, have a lot of means - a lot of means. action and pressure tactics. This need to rebalance the balance of power, we also want it to be taken into account when an employee whistleblower is the subject of measures within his company, so that he belongs to the employer to provide guarantees that this is not retaliation. We make an important proposal: we want independent authorities are established to receive, assist and advise whistleblowers. As we have said, they are often in a fragile situation and left to fend for themselves in the face of powerful organizations and, therefore, this network of independent authorities, with an independent European authority which could ensure coordination and a means of appeal. for whistleblowers, seems particularly important to us. I want to take as an example a case that we will also discuss this week, but which is of a different nature. I think of all those people who have experienced the damage caused by glyphosate. I think of Ms. Grataloup, in particular, who tried to alert Monsanto of the wrongdoing, who tried to alert national authorities and who was not heard. That’s why an independent authority responsible for welcoming whistleblowers would be an important step. But I would also like to underline, for once, a rather contemptible attempt by certain colleagues on the other side of this chamber, who, hand on heart, claim to want to protect whistleblowers, but who, at the same time, , would like in this report to deprive them of any possibility of having recourse to the press. However, it is obvious that it is precisely in the most problematic cases, in the heaviest cases, in the most serious cases - we speak of corruption, we speak of embezzlement - that it is necessary to alert the press; these are the cases in which whistleblowers are most at risk. What sense would it make to want to remove whistleblower protection precisely for those more serious cases that require direct contact with the press? It is no more and no less than denying the right of citizens to quality information and suppressing the sources of investigative journalism. I find it particularly regrettable that while we are going to pay tribute to the courage of Daphne Caruana Galizia, tomorrow at noon, some colleagues are trying to prevent whistleblowers from speaking directly to the press.I hope everyone can see their game and tomorrow noon's votes.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I agree that there should be a legislative framework, ie legal protection for whistleblowers, especially at national level.These whistleblowers, who choose to disclose confidential information about illegal activities, help fight fraud, corruption and tax evasion.However, when enforcing regulation at European level, I recommend that we be very careful.For example, in the area of anonymity, we should talk more about confidentiality, where the identity will be known, but only to the supervisory authorities.I also do not agree with the creation of funds to support whistleblowers, which would be implemented precisely from what will be gained from their activities.I consider this connection to be very dangerous.In short, the right to the protection of whistleblowers is important and a national framework and a very sensitive approach must be respected in a European framework.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
