text: – Mr President, whistle—blowers are essential for protecting the public interest, saving public money and ensuring transparency and integrity in public life. In the light of recent scandals, and particularly following last week’s assassination of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, it is crucial that we adopt an EU-wide protection plan. When protecting whistle—blowers, we also protect journalists and their sources, we protect NGOs and freedom of speech, and we protect the truth. I am proud that my group has played such an important role in promoting EU action for the protection of whistle—blowers, and I want to thank my colleague, Virginie Rozière, for her work on the report. Transparency, democracy, free press and high ethical standards – both in public and private organisations – are the values that we protect when we protect whistle—blowers. We need to stand strong on these, especially when faced with attempts to dilute the substance of the report by some other groups in this House, namely the EPP. We in the European Parliament should lead the way on greater transparency, not pull the curtains shut or close the door.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, at a time when Europe really has millions of unemployed people, millions of poor people and huge public debt at the same time, tax evasion, tax avoidance and, of course, corruption must be tackled decisively. And in this fight, in this struggle, an important role is played by the complainants, who either work in the public or private sector, and really reveal the scandals that are happening. There must, therefore, be a protection for these people and also enable them to come spontaneously. But, if they know they will be punished, it will obviously be very difficult to have the complainants. It is important that we had the Falciani list, what is called in Greece the Lagarde list, which revealed a huge tax evasion, which has also happened in Greece. Protection of complainants, therefore, in the public interest and therefore we should adopt a broad definition of the concept of complainant, take into account mainly the type of information and, of course, have their protection, even financial support, if we want indeed the complainants come and reveal what is happening to the detriment of the public interest.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, whistleblowers, and how they need and deserve our complete protection.I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur and everyone who worked on this great document, because we have needed it before.The European Parliament generally does not lag behind when it comes to issues of publicity, freedom, democracy.We may be a little behind in this matter at the moment, but I believe that we can make quick and clear progress.This document allows us to do just that.I remember some examples from Croatia, a very famous example, of a whistleblower related to the largest Croatian company at the time, INA, the oil industry, and I know what it went through and what situation it was in, all done in the public interest.That is why, in this context, I want to strongly support all the intentions we have, because I am sure that many things will be easier to reveal if Parliament clearly stands on the side of those who wish us only good.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is time for an end to the lip service when we come to talking about whistle-blowers. Everyone says they are wonderful; everyone says they are brave; everyone says they are exceptional. It’s only when we get to a situation where people don’t need to be brave to be whistle-blowers where it becomes normal to be a whistle-blower – then we can say that we have succeeded. At the moment, you have to be exceptional: if you become a whistle-blower in my country, you will be the one ending up digesting the whistle. You will end up unemployed; you will end up mentally destroyed. I have seen this on so many occasions. We have seen situations in my country where whistle-blowers in our police force have had false files and paedophilia charges put against them, since exposed. We have had members of our police force who have had rats hung on their door for exposing wrongdoing. We need to help these people. Either that, or we need to tell them, ‘keep quiet, otherwise your life will be destroyed’. Hopefully this will change it. A good start.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for several years the fundamental role played by whistleblowers in revealing serious violations of the public interest has been highlighted by a series of scandals in very different fields, such as the protection of public health, the environment and tax evasion. Whistleblower protection is one of the most important tools for safeguarding the public interest. Unfortunately, the protections offered, where they exist, are inadequate or too fragmented to ensure a coherent framework within the European Union. Numerous international standards on whistleblower protection have been developed, on which European legislation should therefore be based. According to these rules, the definition of whistleblower should be broad enough to cover a maximum number of situations and thereby protect public and private sector employees, consultants and self-employed workers. Even the case of journalist and blogger Daphne Caruana Galizia, who had been referred to as the "Wikileaks woman", obliges us to do everything we can to protect whistleblowers working to expose misconduct.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, as Commissioner Moscovici told our committee last week, the European Parliament is leading the EU institutions in fighting tax avoidance and money laundering, but we would never have been able to do this without the work of Antoine Deltour: the LuxLeaks whistle-blower whose courage led to the setting up of a series of special tax committees. Daphne Caruana Galizia, the Maltese journalist who was killed by a car bomb last week, gave evidence to our committee about the tax affairs of the rich and powerful in Malta. These two brave people gave us the information we needed to challenge the corrupt and self-serving behaviour of the global plutocracy, behaviour that is shaking the very foundations of our democracy as people lose faith that the system works for them. One was found guilty and barely avoided jail. The other was viciously murdered.  This is the sort of courage it takes to be a whistle-blower in a world without protective legislation. How much corruption remains hidden because those who know about it are too afraid to come forward? The legislation that Parliament proposes today would offer whistle-blowers the protection they need.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revelations of Panama Papers, Swiss Leaks and Lux ​​Leaks are only the latest major scandals that have exposed systems of tax evasion, transnational fraud, corruption, made known thanks to the courageous initiative of those who felt the duty to denounce criminal conduct aimed at damaging the community. I believe that the European Parliament deserves credit for having turned the spotlight on such a delicate and current issue, also highlighting the differences between the national systems of the Member States, in some of which whistleblowers are not protected or, at times, are criminalized. for the action performed. I thank Mr Rozière who, with his work, has highlighted how it is now necessary to have a regulatory framework that provides for minimum standards to harmonize the treatment of such cases and to protect whistleblowers, through the establishment of specific legal rules, so as to recognize them. the fundamental role in the public interest.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about the protection of whistle-blowers, of whistleblowers, and therefore we are talking about a real fight against corruption, a real fight for transparency. But, beyond words, the reality of the facts tells us about a heterogeneous system of rules, which varies from country to country: at this moment in the European Union there are countries that have put in place really strong institutions, truly adequate to what is the challenge, others in which even whistleblowers are criminalized, and even more so it must be said that this protection must be not only formal but also substantial. It is therefore necessary to guarantee the possibility, even for anonymous informants, to be able to operate, it is therefore necessary to protect them from any form of retaliation by employers and the institutions they work for, and for this, in my view , it is essential to reverse the burden of proof. In case of demotion, in case of potentially discriminatory behavior, it is those who carried out them who must demonstrate their good faith and not the informant, on the contrary, who must prove that he was wronged. In addition to this, perhaps we should also think of funds to go to remedy the economic consequences. This is what we must do if we really want to talk about the protection of whistle-blowers, otherwise the courage of their words will be followed only by the silence of our indifference.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we are shocked by the murder of a brave Maltese journalist a week ago.He exposed abuses, corruption and crime.This case is an extreme example of how whistleblowers can go, what risks they take and why they need to be protected.The report contains a lot of good things, such as anonymous reporting channels and financial support for whistleblowers.It goes without saying that small, medium-sized and large companies must be able to operate on a level playing field in the internal market, whether it is in terms of taxation, public procurement or compliance with environmental standards.We need clear legislation for the protection of individuals who expose the abuses and crimes of these companies and communities.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, whistleblowers are of great importance to any society because they are people who endanger their own well-being in order to reveal hidden information of public interest. For such sacrifice, society too often does not express gratitude to them to the extent that they deserve it and allows them to be marginalized. Whistleblower protection therefore imposes itself as a necessity if we want to encourage citizens to disclose information of public interest without hesitation or fear. First of all, I am thinking here of a quality legal framework at national level that should be adopted by all Member States. But I must emphasize that the absolute legal protection of whistleblowers as invoked by the reporter and some colleagues is simply not possible. If we completely prevented the other party, the one who is considered injured, from seeking justice in court, we would de facto legitimize abuse of position, defamation and willful breach of contract. Not all cases are the same and it would not be wise to collectively apply special rules to them. Whether they can be applied to a specific whistleblower case should still be decided by the court.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, both in the public sector and in large corporations, there are some people who take advantage of their position and engage in illegal activities, such as fraud, tax evasion, illicit enrichment and other irregularities, thus creating and perpetuating corruption in general. Reacting to this unacceptable situation, some honest citizens denounce any illegal activities that come to their notice. Unfortunately, many times these people fall victim to their honesty and courage, because they are persecuted for their work, their lives are threatened, the lives of their family members, many times they lose their lives and, in general, they suffer. Because, with these activities, these people help the state to function, the state must protect them and methodize and institute procedures that will help strengthen their willingness to denounce these illegal actions. Here, however, we must be careful not to foster cases of false retaliation and retaliation. We do not want traitors, we want people who will report illegal activities, so that the state works properly with the principles of good administration and the rule of law.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, once again I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur for this report, which is an important contribution to our debate. The Commission strongly believes that protecting those who raise the alarm helps detect serious violations of the law which would otherwise be difficult to identify. Whistle—blowing is an upstream component of the chain of actions necessary for an effective enforcement of the law and the safeguarding of the public interest.  Let me underline that we should protect responsible whistle—blowing which genuinely seeks to protect the public interest. It is essential to safeguard the rights and interests of entities affected by whistle—blower reports, such as their right of defence. The question is how best to achieve this objective, and how we can contribute at EU level. As you know, the Commission is currently finalising its assessment of the scope of such EU action. Our open public consultation conducted this year attracted a lot of interest. We received some 5700 replies, of which around 200 were from stakeholder organisations. The full results are available online, but let me underline that respondents were overwhelmingly in favour of protecting whistle—blowers.  Asked specifically in which areas the European Union should support Member States to better protect whistle—blowers, the top four areas they cited were: the fight against fraud and corruption, the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, the protection of the environment and the protection of public health and safety. To feed our assessment, we have also commissioned an external study. We are carrying out a detailed mapping of the legal situation across the European Union, including through targeted consultations with national authorities and other stakeholders. The Commission will consider further actions in the first part of 2018. In this context, your report is very timely, and the solutions proposed will be taken into account in our work.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 24 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing. - Whistleblower protection requires a deliberate and responsible framework within which the whistleblower is to be protected by law. Exceeding this framework may lead to the degeneration of the system and the creation of tools that could be used by authorities with authoritarian tendencies to fight their political enemies. The repeated ideas to transfer to the accused of abuse the obligation to prove his innocence, instead of demanding from the accuser to present reliable evidence clearly proving guilt, is just such a tool. Similarly to the postulate to create publicly available websites, allowing anyone to anonymously accuse any person without taking responsibility for any harm caused. Journalists should also continue to be protected by press law - they should not enjoy the status of a whistleblower. The press law allows and even orders journalists to protect their informants, but at the same time requires them to thoroughly check information from such a source. Otherwise, journalism could turn into an arena of struggle between various circles. So journalists should not be granted the status of a whistleblower. So let us be prudent not to throw the baby out with the bath water while demonstrating to our voters our uncompromising will to fight for fairness. That the created system of whistleblower protection would really serve the common public interest.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: signed up.- In recent years, whistleblowers inside public institutions or companies have contributed to the disclosure of many frauds or illegal behaviors.But whistleblowers need to be protected from possible abuse.Unfortunately, the protection provided, if any, is still very insufficient and too fragmented to create a coherent framework in the European Union.The protection of confidentiality must be ensured and a reversal of the burden of proof should be introduced;at the same time, provisions should be introduced on financial and psychological support as well as on compensation for damage.But it is essential that the denunciation be well defined, so that people who want personal revenge or promotion do not use this tool for unethical purposes.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- Whistleblowers are essential in a democratic society;yet they are often threatened by legal proceedings as well as reprisals in the workplace.National laws are different from one country to another and often unsuitable.We demand from the European Commission a proposal for legislation to ensure the protection of whistleblowers at European level by the end of the year.The paradox today is to note that whistleblowers are victims of threats, persecution and legal proceedings while, at the same time, those who are denounced are relatively protected.Whistleblowers are the sentinels of our time, and when they serve the public interest, they must be properly protected.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of the report by Laura Agea, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on a guaranteed minimum income policy as a tool to combat poverty (2016/2270 (INI)) (A8-0292 / 2017).

name: Laura Agea
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, citizens, today it is clear to everyone that poverty is a European problem, caused precisely by the policies that this European Union has perpetrated for years. The last hope to put a stop to the emergency of poverty is the will of all countries to adopt a minimum income that restores life and dignity to the nearly 120 million European citizens who are no longer able to make it to the end of the month and they struggle to survive. With this document, Europe will no longer be able to turn away with indifference when it comes to the suffering of its citizens. Europe must no longer remain deaf to the requests for help that families and businesses have been making for years. The European Commission should address the issue of minimum income without delay by presenting the proposal for a binding directive as soon as possible. Today, according to the European Social Observatory, various forms of income support already exist in 26 Member States, and with regret I must add that there is no minimum income in my country. We want Europe to intervene immediately with a common framework of rules that allows the harmonization of the various regimes in force with common access criteria valid for all, such as, for example, basing the calculation of income to be paid on the poverty threshold, which Eurostat sets 60% of the national average income. There are no second-class citizens, everyone must be able to benefit equally from minimum income schemes. Words are no longer enough, the budget lines of the European Social Fund and the European Program for Employment and Social Innovation must be made available to help Member States implement minimum income schemes. It is a strategic and visionary approach that allows for real social integration. It's not just about money: citizens don't ask for alms, but politics of dignity. If they find the money to save the banks, all the more I expect resources to be found for the children of this Europe which is too often the victim of wicked interests.This continent of ours must rediscover its human face, ensuring health care, housing, education and dignity through expansive economic policies for the benefit of all.I would like to conclude by thanking the Commissioner and fellow rapporteurs, but also by saying that this work, this document, bears my signature, bears the signature of the 5 Star Movement, but contains the names of all 120 million European citizens for whom it was written.Our commitment, our dedication and our work have been, are and will always be aimed at citizens.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I cannot resist responding to the rapporteur's call. I just want to point out that the European Union cannot replace the decision-making of the parliaments and governments of the Member States. Nevertheless, the universal minimum income is already a reality in many countries, as she herself admitted, even if it is called differently, for example the subsistence minimum, as we have in the Czech Republic. However, the question is whether there should be any minimum income defined at European level. I personally do not agree with this, just as I do not agree with the definition of a minimum wage at European Union level. However, the adopted wording of this report is acceptable, as it only encourages all states to consider some form of minimum income. Personally, I am opposed to mentioning in the report the possibility of a European Union directive on minimum income, and I do not agree with the call for a European Union fund to be set up. It would be a utopia and a false promise to the electorate, which the European Parliament should reject.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the data on poverty in the European Union are of great concern, given that the austerity policies of recent years have sharpened: 119 million people in the European Union, about 25% of the total population, are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, and to these data must be added the high rates of unemployment, especially among young people. One of my first initiatives as a Member of the European Parliament was to question the Commission about the plight of millions of European citizens who are unable to meet their basic needs. The minimum income of citizenship is a possibility, even if declined with different nuances in the various Member States. Europe must be able to build a common welfare system based on the centrality and leading role of every European citizen. It is necessary to launch an integrated strategy to combat poverty, based on objective indicators and with a precise timetable for implementation, to ensure that the objectives of Europe 2020 are met.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, austerity, violent fiscal adjustment have really led huge sections of the population of the whole of the European Union to poverty and unemployment. We have over 119 million people at risk of poverty in the European Union, or about 25% of the total population. Unemployment mainly affects young people and this is happening throughout the European south, with Greece emerging as a champion in youth unemployment. 40% of the Greek population lives below the poverty line due to the memoranda imposed by the troika that continues the tax evasion policy and at the same time drives Greek citizens away from their homes, since the red loans now result in the troika to impose electronic auctions and crows to grab the houses of Greeks. So a minimum income system is needed, a European minimum wage is needed, there can be funding through the European Social Fund and a directive that enforces the minimum guaranteed income system.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr. president. I want to support the approval of a European framework that establishes the conditions for a minimum income at European level and that encourages the States to understand that this spending is an investment. It is the best known response, after a decent and quality job, to rescue people from marginality, avoid the terrible personal consequences that unemployment produces, provide a solid platform for their reintegration into work and combat poverty. The data speak for themselves: in the Basque Country we believe in social Europe. We have made a sustained and intense effort. The insertion income that works in the Basque Country, which does not reach 5% of the state population, serves 20% of the recipients and accounts for almost 40% of the money spent on this concept in the State. Thus, our at-risk-of-poverty rate does not reach 9%, compared to the 22.3% registered in our Member State, and integration mechanisms also have a decisive influence on our unemployment rates, also the lowest in the State. This is the way.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, to speak of minimum income policies is to speak of the real causes that justify it; it is talking about the reasons why 125 million people live in poverty today in the European Union, which produces 20% of world GDP; it is talking about the reasons why economic and social inequalities are increasing, levels of labor exploitation or precariousness. The answer is clear: it is in the capitalist matrix of the European Union and the policies that it has promoted that are the causes that justify the need for these instruments - transitional instruments that are necessary, but that do not respond to the root causes. These are combated with real disruptions, with the constraints that EU policies impose on States and prevent policies for effective redistribution of wealth, the promotion of decent work with rights, the advances in collective bargaining agreements, the real increase in wages, the fight against inequalities or the guarantee of public, free and quality services, of health, social security and education - in short, progressive development policies that respond to the needs of workers and peoples.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we have a minimum wage in the United Kingdom. It is called a minimum wage, but it is less than the minimum amount a person can live on. Its spending value is lower now than it was nine years ago. In the UK, more than seven million people in working families protected by the so—called minimum wage live in poverty. The latest figures show that 1.1 million people in the UK are using food banks, over a quarter of whom are in work. Only a real living wage will truly tackle in—work poverty. A living wage is a fundamental issue of social justice. It is the most basic economic protection there is. It is a guarantee by each state to its citizens that their work will earn them enough to live off. The introduction of the minimum wage across all EU states is welcome, but it is my sincere hope that we will set our sights on making a minimum wage a living wage.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the wrong economic policy pursued by the European Union over the last decade has caused millions of Europeans, especially in the South, to be living now either on the brink of poverty or in poverty and unemployment, especially among young people. Therefore, in order to deal with this unacceptable situation, a guaranteed minimum income must be introduced in all European countries, so that Europeans can no longer live in poverty. In this context, the European Union must abandon the vicious and unreasonable policy of implementing the memoranda in Greece, which has led to the impoverishment of most of the country's population. It is utterly hypocritical to discuss here the introduction of a guaranteed minimum income for the European citizen and, on the other hand, for the European Union to help Germany plunder the country's land and sea wealth. It is an unacceptable situation that must end.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we have worked a lot and hard to produce this report and for that I want to congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague Laura Agea. But we have worked hard to ask for a consensus, to ask the European Commission for a directive on minimum income. A proposal, in short, that covers the gaps that we have discovered that exist after the harshness of the economic crisis in our social model, in our welfare state. We have to create a new system that protects people who, after more than two years in unemployment, lose their benefit and, therefore, remain on the shoulders of the way out of the crisis, remain in the percentages of people in risk of social exclusion. We want a directive that obliges the Member States to create this system of minimum income; to oblige them to give an amount above 60% of the disposable income of families in each Member State; that it also incorporates labor insertion policies and, therefore, that it makes, from the initiative, from the politics, a fairer and more decent society for the vast majority of citizens who expect from this Europe something more than regrets and something more What percentages, in this case of people living on the poverty line.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the introduction and reinforcement of minimum income policies, if properly combined with other measures and policies related to the social and labor market, can be a way to fight poverty and promote social inclusion and access to the labor market. . I also believe that minimum income regimes can also act as automatic macroeconomic stabilizers in response to economic shocks. In 2015, 23.7% of the population and 12.5% ​​of workers over 18 in the European Union were at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Dear colleagues, Europe is one of the most prosperous regions in the world, but these figures show a harsh and harsh reality that needs to be tackled. The European Social Observatory has reported that 26 Member States already have income support schemes, but there are still many differences between Member States in the treatment of minimum income policies. For all these reasons, I express my agreement with this report, which urges, in particular, all Member States to introduce adequate minimum income schemes, as the last social safety net, as a way of fighting poverty and ensuring a dignified existence at all those who do not have sufficient resources, and proposes that the Commission consider creating an appropriate European Fund, on a temporary basis, that functions as an instrument of European cohesion and society policy.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the guaranteed minimum income, this pride of the European Union and all the parties - liberals, social democrats, far right and fascists - of the opportunists - who support it, is a prime example of hypocrisy for so-called social sensitivity. The people's income, ruined by redundancies, reductions in salaries, pensions, allowances, savage tax raids, finances this supposedly safety net for alms in the most extreme cases of misery and prevention of their explosion. In other words, it divides poverty between the poor and the even poorer with the profits of the monopolies intact. This so-called security is also placed on employees to tolerate further pay cuts, the abolition of collective bargaining agreements - see Macron France, SYRIZA Greece, etc. Employees to discard this Trojan Horse for their last rights. To deny the least evil that always proves to be greater. By organizing and fighting, to claim increased unemployment benefits for all the unemployed, throughout the duration of unemployment, signing collective labor contracts to compensate for losses and wages that meet the needs of employees.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, the idea of ​​a minimum income as a negative income tax that would replace all other social transfers and drastically reduce the administration is increasingly being abused by the economic left. The goal of the guaranteed minimum income, as conceived by Milton Friedman, is not to introduce another social measure at the expense of the productive part of the population, but quite the opposite - to simplify the social system by providing the basic living conditions for everyone, not just some. should work for everyone else. Since employment would not lose the right to a minimum income, as it is usually lost today to various social measures, people would have a greater motive to look for a job in order to earn extra money. On the other hand, those who want to volunteer and engage in humanitarian work would have more time for such activities because they still have a guaranteed basic income. Unfortunately, this report is about something completely different and I would not be able to support it even if it did not dangerously violate the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to express my thanks to Ms Agea for this comprehensive report, which looks into minimum income policies to address poverty. There are now clear signs that Europe is recovering from the crisis. 2017 is the first year since 2008 when all European economies are expected to grow. The recovery is also reflected in the employment and social situation in Europe. Employment has reached the highest number ever recorded: 232 million in 2016. Unemployment rates are back to the pre-crisis level: 7.7% in August 2017. The number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion decreased in more than half of the Member States in 2015 and is back to its pre-crisis level of 23.7%. However, we cannot be complacent, as thousands of our citizens – including people with jobs – are at risk of poverty and social exclusion.  Therefore, I welcome your report as it highlights this challenge. Poverty and inequality are not only detrimental to social cohesion, but also to sustainable economic growth. Addressing these challenges is at the core of the European Semester and the European pillar of social rights. The pillar includes, as key principles, the provision of adequate minimum income schemes, essential services and employment activation. In line with the active inclusion approach, all Member States currently have some form of minimum income scheme. However, their design and implementation vary greatly. Moreover, as the report also points out, income support should be accompanied by access to services and activation, such as lifelong learning, for workers, the unemployed and vulnerable social groups. The European Semester has proved to be an effective framework to monitor and provide guidance to Member States in this area. The pillar will further strengthen these efforts by introducing a new social scoreboard. Moreover, we are currently working with the Member States on a benchmarking framework for minimum incomes. The Commission is also promoting mutual learning and the exchange of good practices among Member States, for instance within the Social Protection Committee, or by supporting the European Minimum Income Network, which aims at the progressive realisation of adequate and accessible minimum income schemes in Member States.

text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 24 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The economic crisis and the processes of globalization are at the origin of an ever greater gap between rich and poor, with a European middle class that in recent years has increasingly slipped into poverty.It is therefore absolutely a priority that a strong protection net be put in place at European level and citizenship income constitutes in this sense a measure capable of restoring dignity to the many who find themselves in extreme difficulty today.This is a battle that the M5S has always waged in Italy, but a European directive in this sense would constitute an important social justice intervention.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - The economic crisis has left a permanent mark on the European labor market with a significant impact on the social fabric. Both the European institutions and national governments have taken and are taking steps to reduce poverty and unemployment. This report on the minimum guaranteed income aims to provide practical guidance on how to intervene simultaneously, on the one hand, to mitigate the social impact of the economic crisis and, on the other, to promote active policies aimed at job creation and ensuring sustainable development. Cyprus is already successfully implementing measures to support the guaranteed minimum income with the aim of providing a social security network for people at risk of poverty. By pooling and streamlining the available resources, through the guaranteed minimum income, the government created an effective social safety net, supporting thousands of Cypriots who needed it and who previously had no state support.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up. - The austerity measures that have dominated European economic policy in recent years have led to economic recession, rising unemployment and reduced job opportunities for many European citizens. I believe that the Member States and the Commission need updated figures on income and living conditions in EU countries, taking into account national specificities, in order to implement a reference budget and a minimum income at European level, used to better combat poverty and test the robustness of the minimum income level and the mentioned threshold, but also respecting the principle of subsidiarity. As such, I consider the rapporteur's proposal to develop a concept at European level on common objectives for national minimum income systems to create a level playing field between Member States to be beneficial. For this, it would be useful for the Commission to carry out an assessment of the impact of minimum income systems in the European Union, with regular monitoring and reporting with a view to future action. In addition, when targeting minimum income schemes, Member States must take into account the at-risk-of-poverty threshold set by Eurostat at 60% of the average national equivalent disposable income (after social transfers), together with other indicators.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing.- Reducing inequalities is one of the overarching objectives of the European Union, enshrined in the treaties.Therefore, although social policy remains the competence of the Member States, also at the EU level, tasks should be undertaken that are to lead to greater social cohesion and raise the standard of living of citizens.The proposal to establish a minimum income is a concept that deserves attention, but it should be borne in mind that the economic differences in social and legal systems between Member States make it impossible to implement it at EU-wide level.Therefore, I have doubts about the introduction of a framework directive on minimum income.Moreover, I believe that people suffering from poverty and excluded from the labor market must first of all gain support in social integration, as well as professional activation.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: written. - "The social divide in Europe is widening. Between young and old. Between south and north. Combating poverty has become a neglected child". Those were my words two years ago. I then asked for concrete proposals to combat poverty. I am pleased that we are discussing today a proposal that we have been waiting for since the 2008 crisis, namely a first step towards a minimum subsistence level for all Europeans. A good thing, because in my opinion everyone in Europe should be able to count on a decent life. This proposal also refers to an (unconditional) basic income. I am not in favor of that in advance. After all, everyone can be expected to contribute to their ability to keep collective facilities affordable for people who, for example, have to deal with illness or setbacks. Of course I would like to be convinced of the opposite. I am curious about the results of the experiments with a basic income. Many Europeans still live in poverty. We cannot accept that. It is time we took this "neglected child" by the hand and do something. Ensuring a decent life in every Member State is a good first step in this regard.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- If the fight against poverty must be one of the most important objectives in Europe which, let us remember, is struggling to recover from the crisis and the austerity policies imposed by the European Union, despite a certain economic recovery, this should not be done at the cost of the sovereignty of the Member States.However, the objective of this report is to establish a European minimum income which would be both financed by the Member States (via the European Social Fund) but managed by the European institutions.Also, we do not accept that national forms of minimum income (such as the RSA in France) can be replaced by a supranational instrument over which France will no longer have control.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. –The Hungarian minimum wage paints a depressing picture in European comparison. Almost everywhere, the minimum wage is higher in Europe than in Hungary. Slovaks, Croats and Poles are also earning more by tens of thousands of forints. Germans receive three times, but even Slovenes twice as much as Hungarians. The gravity of the situation is further exacerbated by the fact that 4 million people in Hungary live in poverty and almost 7 million live overnight, with zero savings. A German or a Danish car mechanic earns three times as much as a Hungarian for the same job. The European Union minimum wage must therefore be set, with which we can increase the wages of Hungarian workers by leaps and bounds. If there is a guaranteed European minimum income at EU level, we can dramatically improve the living standards of Hungarians, they should no longer have to worry about coming out by the end of the month. At the same time, a minimum income could also ensure that equal pay is paid for equal work. The work of a Slovak or a Polish is not worth more than that of a Hungarian.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - Poverty and social exclusion, the causes and duration of which do not depend on the will of those who face them, constitute humiliation of human dignity and violations of fundamental human rights. According to Eurostat, in 2016, in the 28 Member States of the European Union, 23.4% of the population, respectively 117.5 million people, were at risk of poverty and social exclusion, a level almost similar to that before the crisis ( 2008). It is well known that one goal of the Europe 2020 strategy is to remove at least 20 million people from the EU to poverty and social exclusion by 2020. However, international organizations (IMF) have imposed, in the case of some states. Member States, extremely restrictive budgetary austerity policies, which require substantial spending cuts in key areas such as education, health, justice, culture and social assistance and services. Such policy options have led to a sharp increase in poverty and social exclusion. As such, we agree that only a prosperous economy with a low unemployment rate and a minimum income system is the most effective tool for combating poverty.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Derek Vaughan, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on control of spending and monitoring of EU Youth Guarantee schemes’ cost-effectiveness (2016/2242(INI)) (A8—0296/2017).

name: Derek Vaughan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, youth unemployment has been one of the scandals of our time. Some of the youth unemployment rates in some Member States have been an absolute disgrace. Therefore, I am pleased that the EU has done its part to tackle this scandal through the Youth Guarantee Scheme and the Youth Employment Initiative. Between 2013 and 2017 youth unemployment has come down from 23.8% to 16.6%. I am pleased that the EU has put his money where its mouth is. I am pleased we have put more money into the programmes to allow us to tackle this issue. I am also pleased that the programme was front-loaded and pre-financing was increased in order to tackle the problem when it was at its worst. I am also pleased that the EU has now agreed to extend the Youth Employment Initiative up until at least 2020. So all that is good. However, more needs to be done. The programmes got off to a slow start. They were introduced quickly. Many Member States did not have the capacity or the structures to put in place the programmes, and it therefore got off to a slow start and youth unemployment still remains high. It is currently around 18%. Therefore, I would urge Member States not to use EU funds to replace their own funds and programmes, but I would urge Member States to use their own funds to tackle youth unemployment, and not just rely on funds coming from the European Union. I would also urge Member States, companies and trainers to ensure they are offering a good-quality opportunity to young people and not just use them as cheap labour, as we have seen so often in the past. On implementation and monitoring, because after all this is a Committee on Budgetary Control report, I want to say I am concerned that there is sparse data on the output and results of the programmes. Better systems need to be put in place so that the results can be properly measured. We need to know how effective and efficient these programmes are. I would also like to see better market analysis so relevant opportunities can be offered to young people. We want opportunities which would benefit young people, but also benefit the economy. Finally, hopefully we will see an evaluation coming from the Commission soon on these important programmes. This will allow us to make adjustments to improve implementation of these programmes even further. As I said at the start, these programmes have been worthwhile. They have made a huge difference but there is still much to do.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, youth unemployment is a very serious issue, so it is our duty to address it.According to the latest Eurostat statistics, unemployment has fallen sharply.In August 2017, there were 16.7% of young people under 25 in the European Union, and that is indeed a decline.I believe that the European Social Fund, which helped many young unemployed people to find work, also contributed to this.But it is alarming that, for example, in Greece, in Spain, in Italy, the percentages still reach forty or thirty percent.Youth unemployment has huge negative effects on the economy, but also on the young people themselves.Of course, there is a risk of their frustration, radicalization, and every young person who cannot find a job must be of interest to us.That is why I support the continuation and streamlining of these guarantees for young people.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, youth unemployment is a particularly worrying phenomenon. From the perspective of the wider economy it can have long-lasting effects on productivity and growth. From the perspective of individuals it can have the effect of excluding young people from the labour market for an extended period of time, which in turn can affect their job prospects for life. Considering that youth unemployment in the EU reached an alarming high of 23.8% in 2013, I am convinced that we were right to prioritise this particular segment of the labour market. I also believe that the recent fall in unemployment rates was due in part to the Youth Guarantee, its success depending on national factors such as implementation capacity. Although reduced, the youth unemployment rate still remains a concern that needs our particular attention. At the same time, however, we should not lose sight of the issue of general unemployment and the structural reforms needed to efficiently deal with it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as part of the European plan to combat youth unemployment, the "Youth Guarantee" aims to finance active guidance, training and integration into the labor market for inactive young people. These are therefore fundamental objectives, considering that the average unemployment rate in the European Union is 17.8%, with peaks of 45% in Greece, 41.5% in Spain and 35% in Italy. The European Court of Auditors, in its report on the impact of European policies on youth unemployment, however, highlighted that in many countries the program did not ensure the effective integration of young people into the world of work. As regards Italy, in the past I have already reported the persistence of critical issues in some regions, with average delays in payments of around 64 days, even if the data that worries most is the overall effectiveness of the program, that is impact on youth unemployment in individual states. Compared to 64% in Ireland and 90% in France, in Italy only 31% of the young people involved found a job. Clear and adequate strategies must therefore be defined to correct ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, youth unemployment rates are huge in Europe, but mainly in the European South. The champion, unfortunately, is Greece with 45%, mainly due to the memorandum policies that have been imposed. Of course there is also migration of young people. Five hundred thousand young people from Greece have been forced, precisely because of the harsh policy of the memorandum, to emigrate. It is a given that support is needed for the "Youth Guarantees" program, as well as the "Youth Employment Initiative". "Guarantees for Youth" requires 50 billion euros. But what amounts are available, Mr. Avramopoulos? Crumbs. Much larger sums are needed if we are to really tackle the problems of youth unemployment, all at a time when Mr Draghi has so far spent € 1.7 trillion on quantitative easing. Therefore, huge sums are needed to tackle youth unemployment and, of course, abandon the policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the Youth Guarantee has produced some results, especially in Member States that have had a hard time recovering from the crisis and where youth unemployment has been at record levels for years.The rapporteur is well aware of the challenges facing the program today, and the solution could be to adapt the recommended measures to the local context with greater involvement of representatives of employers and educational institutions with a large local or regional impact.I believe that the Youth Guarantee has a future, but calls for additional allocations from national budgets could prove counterproductive.If we take more money from employers through taxes to fund this program, we will reduce their ability to grow and employ and thus limit the success of the program itself.Let's not fall into that trap.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Topic EU youth strategy: what great Sunday speeches we heard about it. Unfortunately, the reality is different. This is what Europe had promised: The Youth Guarantee ensures that all young people without a job will find a job or an internship within four months. We are investing a total of 6.5 billion euros in this. If we weren't a parliament, but a company, many of us would have resignation in our hands. This is what the European Court of Auditors says, and I quote: “In mid-2016, four million young people were unemployed in the EU. Political decision-makers should ensure that no expectations are aroused that cannot be met. ”As a father of seven, I always like to remind people of the eighth commandment: You should not lie. My wish: let's be honest with the people, then the credibility of our politics will also increase! Europe can solve a lot, but not everything. We may even achieve more when we promise less.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, youth unemployment is a long-standing phenomenon.And some Member States of the European Union have been facing an extremely high level for many years.This not only poses major social problems, but is also very costly economically.In Lithuania, due to young people not working, not studying and not attending schools in 2008was lost 0.7 percent.GDP, and already in 2011- 1.1 percent.Therefore, the control of the costs of the European Union Youth Guarantee Initiatives and the ongoing economic monitoring of fertility are very important, providing arbitrary recommendations and advice to each group of beneficiaries, while determining the share of the Member State's financial contribution.I think there is a consensus that projects to reduce youth unemployment, even in the short term, are effective.Research shows that short-term youth employment greatly increases the chances of finding a job in the future.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in my country youth unemployment reaches almost 37%, according to the latest figures, and youth unemployment in Sicily, a region we visited precisely to check how the funds from the Youth Guarantee were spent, comes to a shameful 57%. You understand how impressive these data are and the most impressive thing, which impressed us and also impressed the European Court of Auditors, is that the policy in this region has not been able to put together an efficient payment system. Young people went to work very often and received payments after months. This is a shame, a shame that can be overturned, absolutely, by sending certain parties away. And it is also absolutely necessary to reverse the austerity policies, however, because you understand that if we do not also help businesses create demand and create lasting jobs, we will never be able to get out of this vicious circle of crisis. So, on the one hand, let us free ourselves from parties and, on the other, let us free ourselves from austerity to create lasting demand and jobs.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the celebrations of the European Union and the SYRIZA-ANEL government for the alleged fall in unemployment are provoking. By juggling they baptize the unemployed as inactive job seekers. One hour of employment, and still unpaid, is enough to be considered an employee, and shift work is arbitrarily excluded from part-time employment. In Greece, too, with unemployment at the forefront, the "youth guarantee" means a short break from unemployment, with 300-400 euros, without pension insurance, subsidizing the employer. In other words, recycling of cheap consumable workers for business groups, in replacement of even older ones that are sent to unemployment. This is the condition for the capitalist recovery, which will be paid dearly by workers with lifeless lives, whether they have a job or not. No unemployed without coverage, allowance for the entire period of unemployment, at a level that the unemployed can live with their families. The only answer is the organization of the workers' popular struggle, in order to put obstacles in the capitalist labor galley. To get stronger again ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, providing young people with better opportunities has been a top priority for the Commission. I therefore welcome Mr Vaughan’s report, which comes at the right time. Four years into the launch of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI), our efforts are now paying off. The Youth Guarantee has been an important policy driver to improve the transition of young people from education to work. Setting it up was not easy. It required commitment and political support from Member States and building new partnerships, as well as significant reforms of labour market, education and training policies. But these efforts are now bearing fruit. Since its launch, around 18 million young people have registered and 11 million have received an offer. The youth unemployment rate decreased from a peak of 24% in January 2013 to 16.7% in August 2017. There are now two million fewer young unemployed in the European Union, and one million fewer young people who are not in employment, education or training – the so—called NEETs. The improving macroeconomic context certainly played a role, but young people have managed better on the labour market thanks to the Youth Guarantee. Public employment services have expanded their services and developed new approaches towards the hard—to—reach. Apprenticeship and traineeship reforms have taken place in many countries. The Youth Employment Initiative has directly helped at least 1.6 million young people to receive a job, training or further education. As your report rightly points out, there are still challenges. We take due note of the European Court of Auditors’ Special Report on the impact of these two projects on youth employment. The Youth Guarantee has done a lot to shift the focus to early intervention and not registered needs, and to ensure a new focus on outreach. But addressing young people in more vulnerable situations, who face multiple barriers, remains a challenge. We are committed to helping Member States by providing financial support and policy advice to ensure that all young people can have access to these opportunities. Through the Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) Programme we are, for example, supporting outreach and awareness—raising projects in four Member States and providing mutual learning opportunities. Your report stresses the importance of cooperation between all partners as a crucial part of achieving this goal. Indeed, public employment services, education providers, social partners and youth organisations need to be involved so that we can reach out effectively to all young people and ensure that measures are sustainable and of high quality. Adequate investment is of course a prerequisite for achieving this. Many of the measures of the Youth Guarantee would not have occurred without the European Union’s financial support, namely the Youth Employment Initiative and the European Social Fund. In some Member States, the Youth Employment Initiative is funding the vast majority of youth guarantee measures and has been instrumental in setting up schemes. Despite a slow start, implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative sped up between 2015 and 2016: the number of young people supported by the Youth Employment Initiative tripled. The recently agreed increase of the Youth Employment Initiative’s budget by EUR 2.14 billion will help to continue this effort, but I fully agree with you that Member States also need to invest in youth employment in order to effectively implement Youth Guarantee schemes and really reach all young people. As regards monitoring requirements on the progress of the YEI, we have been providing guidance and requesting feedback from the Member States on data collection and monitoring. The provision of guidance will continue on a regular and ad—hoc basis. Collecting relevant information and feedback on the results on the ground is essential in order for us to be able to report on the achievement of the Youth Employment Initiative. To facilitate this dissemination of the Youth Guarantee’s results, on 26 October we are organising a Youth Guarantee Learning Forum. This will bring together Youth Guarantee policy coordinators from Member States and YEI managing authorities to disseminate good practices, take stock of the lessons learned so far and come up with proposals for the future.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - Despite its slight decline, youth unemployment remains, with 18.8% in 2016, at an unacceptable level. It is, moreover, only the most visible aspect of a massive precariousness of European youth, which mortgages the future of an entire generation and destabilizes the socioeconomic balance of the States concerned through tax revenues and systems. retirement, but also the birth rate, which has fallen sharply in France. The austerity imposed by the Commission makes any investment of 50.4 billion euros per year necessary for the operation of the “Youth Guarantee”, instituted in 2013, illusory. In addition, the absence of a definition of “offer” of quality ”leaves the door open to the abuses associated with public employment assistance mechanisms, from the windfall effect to jobs without prospects. Thus, it is illusory to think that only a public support mechanism would allow the four million young Europeans to get out of the rut. It is imperative to address the causes of youth unemployment: on the one hand, the shortcomings of secondary and vocational training and, on the other hand, the pressure on personnel costs weighing on companies, subjected to ruthless international competition. .

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. - In its report, the Court of Auditors showed that little progress has been made in implementing the EU Youth Guarantee schemes. Suffice it to mention that there are over 4 million unemployed people under the age of 25 in the entire Union. In some Member States, up to a quarter of young people are unemployed. For the Youth Guarantee, the Court of Auditors' auditors found that the primary source of failure was the lack of strategies with clear milestones and targets. In many Member States, the target group has not even been defined with sufficient precision. Thus, it was difficult to reach all people who needed employment, further education or apprenticeship. Often, no data was collected to measure the achievement of the reported results. The operation of the programs did not live up to the Commission's expectations, but most of all it has disappointed disadvantaged young people. Therefore, it is necessary to draw conclusions from the current practice and think about how to increase the effectiveness of these programs. Certainly, a comprehensive review of the costs related to the Youth Guarantee should be made and programs should be adapted to the available financial resources. In addition, the Commission should ensure that Member States justify how Union-funded youth employment actions respond to existing needs. These changes should be made quickly because we cannot afford to waste the next years.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: written. - Although the European Union's unemployment rate is now at its lowest level since 2008, the protracted economic crisis is still reflected in the lives and prospects of too many young people. The best answer to youth unemployment is skills and education. Education is the most effective way to prevent unemployment. There is a need to further improve both the quality of basic education and access to further education in all Member States of the European Union. It is about the growth of the whole of Europe and the competitiveness of the future. We face common challenges such as an aging workforce, skills shortages, technological developments and global competition. Increased international competition and the advancement of digitalisation and robotization mean major changes in working life. Education must provide every young person with adequate basic skills and competences, but it is at least as important to enable them to update their skills during their careers. It is important that no young person is left empty-handed, but quickly caught up in learning or work. Reforms of rigid education systems and labor markets are still needed in many countries to achieve the Youth Guarantee and reduce youth unemployment. Member States need to be effective in their youth guarantee activities and their monitoring. Investing in youth and education is the key to a better future for Europe.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!The last year has revealed the scale of interference by the services of the Russian Federation in the course of democratic elections in many European Union member states.The last example was last week in the Czech Republic.The Russian Federation uses multilingual TV channels, think tanks, and employs trolls and zombie computers to conduct political disinformation and propaganda designed to discredit the European Union, undermine its unity and destroy cooperation between individual countries.At the same time, it supports populist and nationalist parties.In my opinion, we cannot remain indifferent to this hidden aggression against our community, and that is why I would like to ask the Commission to thoroughly analyze this phenomenon and propose effective tools and ways to counteract these dangerous practices by the Russian Federation.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we have recently been discussing the future of the European Union and Mr Juncker announced the establishment of a European Supervisory Authority on Member States' compliance with European law and in particular the enforcement of judgments to eliminate social dumping and rightly so .
