Should not the European Union protect the fundamental rights of European citizens in Cyprus?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Mr Avramopoulos, I convey to you the cry of agony and protest of the people of Samos and the rest of the Aegean islands who can no longer stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. Yesterday, Sunday, October 21, I attended Samos and spoke at a large gathering of residents, who demand the decongestion of the island, the decongestion of the "hotspot", where more than 4,000 refugees and illegal immigrants are stacked, while the available accommodation places in There are no more than 800. The gathering was also attended by several of the trapped refugees seeking to go to other European Union countries. Mr Avramopoulos, it is necessary to take measures to decongest the Aegean islands. Implement the decision of the Council of State for the promotion of illegal immigrants. Finally, the relocation program from Greece to other European Union countries must be continued, as the previous one was carried out only by 1/3. It is characteristic that, out of the 17,209 who had to leave Greece for Germany, only 4,447 people have left ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, the adoption of the clean energy package in the bodies of the European Union, including the European Parliament, is underway.There are many areas of energy policy where innovations are expected, and without these innovations it will not be possible to achieve the goals set within that energy policy.I would just like to point out some of these areas such as, say, new biofuels, such as new energy storage techniques, including batteries, and such as new materials in the field of energy efficiency of buildings.But what I want to mention in particular and call on the Commission to develop specific sectoral policies, for example in the field of transport in the context of new innovations in the field of clean energy, and something else I want to emphasize, and that is the need not to leave rural areasthis opportunity is used with new technologies and to reduce development in the northern European Union.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, guaranteeing the population's access to safe and drinking water involves acting in the face of the risks and threats of water pollution.Today, I want to call the attention of the European Commission to open an independent investigation into the hazardous waste that is being buried in the old mine of Touro to determine if they are being treated correctly and, thus, to avoid the pollution of the waters of the river Ullaand the Arousa estuary.Photos like these show and make us suspect that, possibly, the waste that is being buried in this old mine does not have the proper treatment.On the other hand, I also want to draw attention to the danger that glyphosate poses to waters and to urge the European Commission to ban this herbicide permanently.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. president. Today I speak to express rejection and amazement. Rejection. The Spanish Government conducts its anti-Catalan campaign along paths that may coincide with hate crime, not only for denouncing and imprisoning social leaders with a clean, peaceful, exemplary trajectory, but also for announcing that it is going to completely eliminate Catalonia's autonomy. The Government may disagree with the separatist project, but it cannot, if it is democratic, annul the decisions of Catalan citizens who, democratically and by an absolute majority, have elected their parliamentarians and their Government. Democracy only eliminates those who are inspired by authoritarian and dictatorial principles. After Franco, it is the first time that it happens in Spain. And stupefaction. How is it possible that democratic Europe approves authoritarian methods in Spain when it rightly denounces them in other countries? I am a MEP and I am ashamed that my Parliament has not yet resolutely stood up in the face of such indignity. Is that dialogue? Is that what Europe wants? I am working for a different Europe; The one I see now, I like it less every day.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to denounce in this house, in this House of European citizens, yet another scam against democracy which is taking place in my country, in Italy.In practice, a few months before the national elections, the majority, which in Parliament was elected with an unconstitutional law, is changing the rules of the game and is doing so to keep out the only real opposition force that has existed, that isthe 5 Star Movement.He is doing it using the institution of "trust", as Benito Mussolini did in 1923 with the Acerbo law, that is, the trust in the electoral law.This is an appeal I make to you, colleagues: it is good that we talk about it in other countries, because it is a shame for democracy and it is something on which we ask for your help.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: - Mr. President, in Greece, seven years later and three memoranda of unemployment, reductions in wages, pensions, allowances, flexible employment, wild tax evasion, the majority of the people are unable to pay loans and taxes. The European Union and the European Central Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the SYRIZA-ANEL government in the evaluation of the third memorandum agreed on another capital increase of the banks, liquidating the red loans to give new to viable, ie big companies. and small and very small businesses from the market. Thousands of bank accounts of salaried, retired and self-employed people are already being confiscated, thousands of electronic auctions of popular housing or the sale of loans to the ravens of non-profit funds are being hastened. Virtually no protection is provided even for the first home, salary and pension. The theft of public property is huge. The popular mobilizations with the demand "legislation now banning auctions of the first house, confiscation of salary and pension, write-off of interest and haircut and freezing of loans" should be strengthened with the slogan "hands off the houses and the sweat of the people".

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: - Mr President. Every day, thousands of our citizens travel to other Member States for work, education or tourism. Many of them use air transport for this. In all circumstances, these citizens must be sure that they will reach their destination safely, on time and without unnecessary expenditure. We cannot accept that airlines will not be informed of long-term flight cancellations in good time. We cannot accept that passengers will be refused compensation for the damage they have caused them through their own fault. And he cannot accept situations where people remain stuck at an airport in a foreign country, without means and without information in their native language. Ladies and gentlemen, in emphasizing air safety and the reliability of air transport, we must first and foremost care about the rights of the people who use it. I therefore believe that, as we discuss the unacceptable abuse of position of large companies against smaller and cheaper competition this week, we will have a discussion very soon on a significant improvement in air passenger rights, because it really is ... (interrupted by the President due to the expiry of time limit)

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: - Mr President.Last week we commemorated World Poverty Day.I would like to mention two important facts in this regard.Firstly, the Europe 2020 strategy is as ineffective in combating poverty as the Lisbon Strategy once was.What is worse, more and more people are at risk of poverty despite having a job.Secondly, the poverty threshold is different in each Member State.In France or Germany, a person with an income of less than a thousand euros a month is considered poor.This is more than the median income of most citizens in up to twelve Member States.Europe must start taking the fight against poverty seriously.The incomes of almost half of its citizens do not even reach the poverty line in Germany and France.Until that changes, we will never defeat the populists.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr President, today I want to convey here the serious situation of discrimination suffered by the Extremadura region as a result of the stoppage of the high-capacity and electrified railway line that was being planned. Stopping this line that also connects Madrid with Lisbon with a view to improving the single market in the Union as a whole is a bad decision and I hope that from now on the Commission and the set of European institutions will help with the immediate implementation of this center line. I would also like, in relation to this matter, to highlight the need to implement - for this the sensitivity of the Commission is necessary - for Asturias, Galicia and Castilla y León, the rail connection of the maritime ports of Vigo, La Coruña, Gijón and Avilés—, in order to be able to close a communications loop in the whole of the Spanish northwest. In recent years we have made great strides in infrastructure, but we need many more.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my constituents are alarmed at the threat to Coleman’s mustard factory after the announcement that Britvic, who share the same site, are closing their operations. Coleman’s mustard is Norfolk through and through, and Norwich is where the jobs must stay. The 200-year-old larder staple is quintessentially East Anglian, made in Norwich with English mustard seeds from Norfolk, Cambridgeshire and Lincolnshire, and it is enjoyed across the world. The decline of manufacturing jobs is not written in stone, and 10 000 people have already signed the EDP petition to say that we do not want to see much-needed jobs that are vital for the Norwich economy lost, and we do not want to see the 200-year Norwich and Coleman’s link severed. So my message is clear: Norwich does not just have a fiery condiment: we have fiery campaigners too. So, Unilever, please come up with plans and reassurances that really cut the mustard.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen,Three million people in Romania - a huge number for a country of twenty million - signed a motion to hold a referendum to defend the natural family system based on marriage and parenthood.This is a great example of the rebirth of civil society, the sense of responsibility for the common good, the reconstruction of the Christian opinion after decades of suffering from communism.Unfortunately, this great initiative has faced attacks in this Parliament as well.It is hard to believe, but there were voices calling on the Romanian authorities to prevent this referendum from being held.This, unfortunately, is another very dangerous signal that proves that this totalitarian drift is growing in our institutions, in the structures of European power.In this situation of our Romanian friends, one thing must be assured: you are not alone, good will prevail, we are with you.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the ongoing elections in Kosovo and Macedonia and in the other Western Balkan countries clearly show that these countries are actually solving their serious problems in a serious way. Quite recently, we had the constitutional crisis in Macedonia and actually they solved it. On the other hand, we, the European Union, are not doing much more than talking. If you look at the money we are giving these countries you will find that the Member States that are receiving money are receiving EUR 3000 per capita. In the Western Balkans the best case figure is EUR 300, and in the worst case the figure is EUR 4 per capita, in Bosnia-Herzegovina. This is actually shameful. If we want enlargement, and if these countries are seriously doing something towards enlargement, then we have to play our part as well and increase that financial help.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, last week Ireland was hit by Storm Ophelia. Homes, farms, businesses roads, schools even sports stadiums fell victim to massive structural damage. Unfortunately, lives were also lost. Government politicians have been quick to call for applications to the European Solidarity Fund, although they are aware that the threshold has not been reached for this third consecutive catastrophic storm. One reason for this is that, in 2015, the threshold for Ireland to apply for Solidarity Funds was EUR 803 million. This year, however, the threshold is EUR 1.2 billion. The story is the same for the regional thresholds based on GDP: Irish regions have seen leaps of between EUR 58 million and EUR 333 million in the amount of damage they must incur to apply for funds between 2015 and 2017. This is a result of distorted GDP figures famously described as ‘leprechaun economics’, and we now need to cut out those figures. On the EU side, too, there is a need to review the Solidarity Fund, as it discriminates against rural and peripheral regions. It is harder for regions to meet the threshold if they have poorer infrastructure to begin with.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, every year 1.4 million Europeans develop some form of dementia, and the World Health Organisation estimates that 6.4 million people in the European Union are currently living with dementia, either the most common cause of dementia or Alzheimer’s disease. There is no cure to halt or treat the disease but there are treatments that delay progression or alleviate the symptoms. Emphasis is now being placed on the standard of care, ensuring dignity for those who have dementia, ascribing to a rights-based approach. There is also a gender dimension to dementia, with Alzheimer’s disease mainly affecting women, and women play an important role in caring. I think much more could, and should, be done at EU level to coordinate the research – into both care and prevention – that is being carried out at Member State level. We can improve diagnosis and post-diagnostic services if we foster dementia-friendly communities. I would suggest establishing an EU coordinator to ensure that this issue is addressed at the highest level, because a lot of information is not being shared across Member States.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE).
text: - Not only in the context of youth unemployment, but also, as Madame Záborská has already mentioned, in the context of the fight against poverty, it is very important to look ahead to the 'Digital Summit' to be held in Lisbon from 5 to 7 November. I asked for the floor because I consider it very important that we deeply improve integration, deep internal European integration, by deepening the digital skills of young people, including the poorest. In Hungary, for example, 94% of students have a smartphone, and the EU could and has created by 2019 to have broadband, high-speed internet available even in the last small village, even in the last ghettos. It is time for the EU to develop a mobile application that can really bring about real desegregation among the poorest, the young, by bringing services to these areas, using mobile applications, in the hands of children. It is very important that they play a role not only in education, but also in health prevention, training and job creation among young people.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is an honour to speak for the first time in this Parliament as its newest Member, and in doing so let me first pay tribute to my predecessor, Glenis Willmott, who made a distinguished contribution to this Parliament, my Group and indeed my party.  I speak today on an issue that should unite this Parliament: the issue of mental health. This is our first plenary since World Mental Health Day and, as we see the impact of austerity bite, we see mental health services such as those in the UK stretched to breaking point. It is time for our Member States and their governments, and indeed this European Union, to redouble our efforts to improve that situation, to secure parity of esteem between mental health and physical health and to eradicate mental health stigma and discrimination.  Our job as parliamentarians is to be a voice for those who cannot be heard. On this issue, that task is more important than ever. Together, we can address this challenge and make sure those people who need a voice on this issue have many voices in this Parliament.

name: President. –
text: Mr Palmer, welcome to this House. It is good to have you with us.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as we live in an ever more deeply interconnected world, we rely more on online services. And it is not just our laptops or gadgets which are connected, it is public institutions, governments and our very own homes. However we make sure we stay safe in this online realm, and that our personal or government data is not hacked into and our democratic processes are not tampered with, I believe the cybersecurity package presented by the Commission last month takes the right approach to ensure we have a concrete European response to potential cybersecurity threats. International and operational cooperation amongst Member States is key, and can only be achieved by bridging the divides between the internal and external, the public and private and the civil and military that exist within our Member States and the EU. The creation of EU cybersecurity standards and certification frameworks will help businesses and citizens to understand when products are cybersecure and improve trust in digital services. The interconnected world we live in is exhilarating, but it also poses potential challenges to every single one of us. I hope that this proposal will be debated thoroughly in this House.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, Croatia is fulfilling its last tasks in order to enter the Schengen area.How important this is for our economy, especially for tourism, I will remind you that in Istria there were kilometer-long columns at the border crossings in the sixth month because Croatia is not a member of Schengen.That is why I call on the Commission to do everything, even non-bureaucratic measures, with strong political support, for Croatia to enter the Schengen area as soon as possible, because this will further contribute to the stabilization of the situation in the Western Balkans.Also, Croatia is currently making the right preparations for the Eurozone, for joining the Eurozone, for the process of joining the Eurozone.Here, too, I expect strong support from the Commission for our country, because Croatia deserves to enter both the Schengen area and the Eurozone.Do everything by political methods to solve this problem for our country as soon as possible.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, according to news made public, the European Commission announced last week the suspension of the third pillar of the Banking Union. Surprised by the surprises, there was no consensus at the Council level on a proposal that was, in itself, a step backwards from the much-publicized creation of a common deposit guarantee system. It was evident, for a long time, that the Deposit Guarantee System was the carrot with which the stick of the usurpation of national sovereignty, centralization and banking concentration was accompanied. This is a development that is not surprising. Even if the third pillar had advanced, this would not change the nature of the Banking Union project. But to those who naively looked at the carrot and to those who deliberately waved at it, to those who guaranteed the attack on national sovereignties in the supervision and intervention on the respective banking systems, to those who thus defended the monopoly concentration on a European scale, saying that the the consolation prize would be what has now fallen to the ground, the question arises: are they available to change their position?

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Venezuelan regional elections of October 15, the result of which Nicolas Maduro proclaimed as a devastating victory, constituted yet another sad episode in the long process of erosion of democracy in that country. First, we are witnessing an election campaign in which officialism has shamelessly instrumentalized public media to favor its candidates. Then, after the vote, there were numerous irregularities reported, including last minute changes and without public notification of polling stations or forced votes in exchange for food. The regime now requires elected officials to take an oath before the fraudulent National Constituent Assembly. An electoral act that should have been carried out last year was transformed, by the PSUV, into a plebiscite to its ruinous governance, which will condition the presidential elections of 2018. This new farce and the worrying impact of the humanitarian crisis should make us increase the pressure against the Maduro regime and, therefore, I repeat that, given the seriousness of this political and humanitarian crisis, it becomes urgent for the Union to adopt individual and selective measures against those responsible, including for possible crimes against humanity, in the words of the High - UN Commissioner for Human Rights.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - While recent action against hate speech has caused serious difficulties for authorities worldwide, incitement messages against the Hungarian minority living in the country have become regular in print and audiovisual media in Romania. These messages, which despise Hungarians, disregard the facts and ignite ethnic hatred, can be uttered with impunity from the mouths of widely known television presenters, journalists or even academics in the Romanian media. The phenomenon is now making its mark on political life, effectively paralyzing the already stagnant and partial dialogue between the majority and the minority. The social effects are clear, according to surveys, the rejection of the Hungarian minority is growing, and no one in the Romanian political elite is speaking out against the phenomenon. He wants to celebrate the 100th anniversary of Romania's existence next year, and so far only one educational or outright hostile message has been sent to the one and a half million Hungarians who have lived in this country for a hundred years.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Father Shay Cullen is an Irish priest working with vulnerable children in the Philippines since the early 1970s. In his experience, sex offenders travel from the European Union and beyond to the Philippines to abuse children, and he has many, many horrific cases which he is dealing with. He has called on my country, Ireland, and other countries in Europe to stop convicted child sex offenders traveling abroad, by taking their passports from them or preventing them from getting a passport. There is a precedent in this – Australia passed legislation in July to stop registered sex offenders from traveling by removing their passports.  We should heed the words of this priest – he knows what he is talking about. As we protect, or try to protect, our children in our own countries, the least we could do is afford the same level of protection to children elsewhere. Where we know a sex offender is convicted in our Member State, we should stop them traveling to do their evil deeds elsewhere.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, swordfish with excess cadmium and heavy metals, dietary supplements and foods with unauthorized ingredients and novel foods, peanuts from China and chillies from India contaminated with carcinogenic aflatoxins, peppers from Turkey with pesticides beyond limits: these are just some of the most dangerous products for health listed by Coldiretti, the largest association representing agriculture in Italy. The data emerge from a dossier drawn up on the basis of the latest report on the European Rapid Alert System, which records alerts for food risks occurring due to chemical residues, mycotoxins, heavy metals, microbiological pollutants, dioxins, additives and dyes. We need more guarantees for European consumers, we cannot rely solely on the European alert system. Europe needs to do much more in terms of traceability, labeling and transparency to prevent potentially dangerous products from reaching the tables of millions of European consumers.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last year, on 7 July here in Strasbourg, we launched a proposal to you that in the post-Brexit conditions we should take a first step towards consolidating a homogeneous Europe of 27 by rethinking territorial distribution. of the Union institutions. At that time, I made known to you my intention to initiate and support the relocation of the European Medicines Agency from London to Bucharest. Today I come before you and tell you: my colleagues from the Romanian government have prepared one of the best offers for the relocation of EMA. I invite both you and the decision makers in the matter of EMA relocation to look objectively at Romania's offer and, together, to reach the correct relocation solution for the agency, whose place may be in Bucharest. The relocation of EMA to Romania could be the first real signal regarding the cohesion of the European Union, but also an equally firm political signal in the direction of combating the idea that the members of the European Union are equal only on paper. The relocation of the EMA is not just an administrative act generated by the outcome of Brexit, but is, first and foremost, a decision with a broad political burden, the consequences of which will be seen later.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, over the past months the level of violence across the Oromo and Ogaden regions of Ethiopia has hugely increased. Human rights groups continue to raise concerns over the use of excessive and unnecessary force by the state in response to peaceful protests. These developments take place after years of human rights violations by the state against Ogadeni, Somali and Oromo groups, including arrests and systemic violence against women, documented by the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organisation (UNPO). The recent outbreaks of cholera in the country have increased the uncertainty of the situation. I am ashamed that the European Union has not yet made a statement on this worrying situation. As Ethiopia’s long-standing partner, the European Union should express its concern over the growing unrest and address the human rights abuses being perpetrated against minorities. Ethiopia is a crucial actor for security in East Africa. There must be a democratic and inclusive dialogue among groups in Ethiopia in order to de-escalate the tensions and bring about lasting peace and stability.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, since 2010, what was to be a rescue plan for Greece has turned into a succession of economic diktats in the name of servicing a debt, which we knew from the start was unsustainable. Now, here we learn that these aid plans - with catastrophic consequences for the Greek people - were the occasion of a lucrative operation for the European Central Bank, bringing it 7.8 billion euros in dividends and redemption of bonds at broken prices. This considerable sum must be returned unconditionally to the Greek treasury, otherwise the operations of the Central Bank could be nothing more than speculation and an instrument of collective punishment. On the other hand, Greece having left the excessive deficit procedure since September, it is high time that the Eurogroup keep its November 2012 commitments in terms of restructuring the Greek debt. This is a necessity. We must return the money to the Greeks!

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. president. Today is the seventh night of Jordi Sánchez and Jordi Cuixart in jail: seven days and seven nights deprived of their freedom, accused of something they have not done. Political prisoners in the middle of the 21st century European Union, because they are not in jail for what they have done, but for what they represent and what they think and, meanwhile, illustrious corrupt people roam at ease. If truth and justice mattered, they would be free. But how is the truth going to matter if even the Spanish Foreign Minister affirms, with all the impudence in the world, that many of the images of the police violence on October 1 are false? The only thing they care about is punishing a country that has dared to vote, which has dared to exercise the right to self-determination despite the blows. And if to punish they have to endanger democracy and shape the rule of law at will, no problem: they do it quietly, protected as they are by their state nationalism. And Europe, does the truth matter? Do you care about fundamental rights or do you only care in distant countries and distant situations? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr. President, the SYRIZA-ANEL government in Greece, no matter how provocatively it tried to portray the Trump administration as a wolf to a sheep, made great and dangerous commitments with Tsipras' visit to the United States. Time expansion and upgrading of Souda and other bases to make the imperialist plans more effective, equipment of 2.4 billion for NATO needs, while no one can restrain himself from government statements on nuclear. Promoting the interests of the United States 'monopolies through investment is stepping on the remnants of popular workers' rights. The geostrategic upgrade of the interests of the Greek bourgeoisie, which is welcomed by the government and all the bourgeois parties, consolidates Greece to the detriment of the people as a base for imperialist interventions and wars. There is a need to intensify the daily popular struggle to condemn the new, even more dangerous agreements of the SYRIZA-ANEL government with the United States in rupture with the power of capital and with imperialist organizations, such as NATO and the European Union.

text: Colleagues, the list has been completed. That concludes the item.
